answer: When I was in third grade, I had a friend named @PERSON2. His mom was always in a bad mood, never laughing or smiling. Every time I saw her and smiled, she'd just frown and keep walking. At first, I thought she didn't like me. When @PERSON2 told me his mom was a grouch, I laughed, and so did he. We laughed so hard we got in trouble in class. The next day at school lunch, @PERSON2 said I was good at making people laugh. I disagreed, saying my jokes were bad. He suggested we test them on a new student. We searched the whole school but couldn't find one. Then the bell rang, and we went to class. In class, our teacher @PERSON1 announced a new student, @ORGANIZATION1. She sat between @PERSON2 and me. @PERSON2 encouraged me to tell her a joke. I asked @ORGANIZATION1 if she wanted to hear one. I started the "boo" joke. At first, she didn't get it, but during the movie, she understood and laughed. @PERSON2 said, "I told you so." @PERSON2 had the idea that if I spent the night at his house, I could make his mom laugh. I thought it was a good plan. I asked my mom, and she said it was okay as long as it was okay with his mom. @PERSON2 asked his mom, and she agreed. When I got to his house, we played video games first. At dinner, @PERSON2 told me to tell the joke to his parents. I did, and they laughed for about five minutes. @PERSON2 said it worked, and his mom asked what. He explained everything. His mom said her mom had recently died, which was why she was in a bad mood. After dinner, we went to bed. The next morning, when my mom came to pick me up, she asked how the sleep - over was. I said it was fun as I made people laugh. She said laughter wouldn't help me clean my room, and I just thought, "Gosh darn it.

Softball is one of the greatest sports, and playing it in college has always been my goal. I love the dirt on my face, the sweat on my forehead, and the water I pour on myself to stay cool in the heat. However, the memories with teammates are what I cherish most in my softball career. I played for the Hood @CAPS1 @CAPS2 team for almost four years. The girls on the team were like sisters to me, and I thought I'd play with them throughout high school. But as my fifth year approached, my dad suggested I try a non - local team. This presented a dilemma: stay with the familiar team or join an unknown team with better players who might not like me. At first, I decided to stay with the familiar team to be comfortable. But as softball season neared, I re - evaluated. I wondered if I should challenge myself to become a better player and attract college scouts. So, I decided to try out for the new team. On the way to the try - out, I was extremely nervous. When I arrived at the field, the girls were friendly. They introduced themselves, and I laughed throughout the try - out. Playing with this team was amazing. The friendships I made would not have happened if I hadn't taken the chance. Softball is not just about the game but also about making new friends and having fun.

I absolutely love making people laugh. Even as a little kid, I was "special" and a huge spaz. I was the most hyperactive five - year - old. For instance, I once hit myself in the head with a hammer and another time stabbed myself in the head with a pencil while dancing in class and needed stitches. A few days before a photo session, I convinced my mom to let me go outside. I fell on the sidewalk corner, ruining the pictures. In kindergarten, I loved school, except for the bullies. There was one bully who gave me wedgies at story time. One day in kindergarten, like any other day, I went to school, did my work, and had break. At story time, I got a wedgie. After the story, I told a really funny joke, and the whole class laughed. Not realizing they were laughing at the joke, I burst into tears. A teacher explained they were laughing at the joke, and it took me a while to stop crying. Even now, my classmates remind me of that day. Although it was a negative experience then, it's now a blessing. It taught me to tell the difference in laughter and accept being laughed at. Being "special" is what makes me who I am and helps me grow.

When I hang out with my friend, we laugh a lot, sometimes for no reason. We laugh about running into trash cans, laundry, and the food we eat. One day at school, the bell rang, and students were going to lunch. My friend, who walks slower than me, was holding onto my backpack. She told me not to cross the hallway, but I did. She slid into a trash can on the wall. The sound was so funny that I still laugh about it. My friend and I have an inside joke about laundry. When we saw a laundry mat, we made up a silly idea of wearing aprons with colors and rhinestones to do our laundry all at once. After the laundry was done, we'd pick out a new clean outfit. About food, one day I talked about dinner. My mom asked if we wanted chicken, and we were excited. But when dinner was ready, it was frozen from a box and looked terrible. These are the things that happen in my life almost every day. I love my friend. We can't stay mad at each other after a fight. At the end of the day, we just ask if we're done being mad and then laugh. Laughter and having fun are what matter most in our friendship.

I'm going to tell a story about the time I got lost downtown. I was going downtown to meet someone. It was cold, dark, and creepy. On the way, I thought I'd gone too far, so I took the bus. I was confused about where I was. I asked a man, and he said I was downtown. I called the person I was meeting. She told me to stay on the bus and come further downtown. I waited for about @NUM1 minutes, and the bus came. I called her to say I was on the way. When I arrived, they laughed at me. I said it wasn't funny as I could have had something bad happen to me. Later, I wanted some candy. They showed me how to get to the store. On my way to the store, I was cold and listening to music. When I got to the store, my phone rang. The girl called to make sure I wasn't lost. A few minutes later, when I walked out of the store, I got lost again. I didn't want her to know, so I didn't call her. After a while, she called and said she could see me going the wrong way. She came up to me, and we laughed. When we got to her house, they laughed again. I admitted I got lost. Later, I realized next time I should ask her to come with me. The whole night was about me getting lost, but it ended up being kind of funny.

I'm going to tell @CAPS18 a little story. One time, at @CAPS11 house in @LOCATION1, @LOCATION2, I was with @CAPS11 cousin @PERSON1. I was bored and asked @PERSON1 what we could do. @PERSON1 suggested making a snowman, and I thought it sounded like fun. When @PERSON1 started reaching for a jacket and gloves, I stopped him and asked what he was getting them for. He said he wasn't cold, and I replied that I'd warned him. We began building the snowman by making the base, the biggest piece for the bottom. After about @NUM1 minutes, the base was almost done, but we started to feel cold. @PERSON1 suggested going inside, saying his mom might make us hot chocolate. So, we went inside, hoping for some warm, delicious hot chocolate. When I saw @CAPS11 mom, I asked if we could have some hot chocolate. She said of course and that we looked cold. @PERSON1 and I sat downstairs by the heater, waiting anxiously for our hot chocolate. When @CAPS11 mom called from upstairs that it was ready, we rushed down the hall and up the stairs. To our surprise, there was not only hot chocolate but also a bag of chips. We thanked @CAPS11 mom and sat down at the table to drink our hot chocolate while she put some chips on paper towels for us. I started eating the chips by the handfuls, but @PERSON1 grabbed just one. I asked him why he only took one. He looked at me from the corner of his eye, slowly brought the chip to his mouth, and took a bite. I fell out of my chair laughing hysterically. @CAPS11 mom heard me hit the floor and came upstairs to find me laughing. She asked what was so funny. I told @PERSON1 to show her, and he grabbed another chip, looked at her from the corner of his eye, and took a bite. I started laughing again, but @CAPS11 mom didn't see the humor. I tried to mimic what @PERSON1 did but with no effect. I even spilled my hot chocolate on myself, which made him laugh. He then offered to show me, and I begged him to. He grabbed another chip, looked at me from the corner of his eye, and took a bite. I laughed uncontrollably for about @NUM1 minutes. I said I'd get it right, and @PERSON1 told me to keep trying. I tried again and again but still couldn't make him laugh the way I wanted. Finally, I did something that made him laugh, and I knew that laughter had brought @CAPS11 cousin @PERSON1 and me closer together.

My best friend, @PERSON1, and I have been close since we were @NUM1. We met through @CAPS1 @CAPS2 lessons at our local dance studio. Over the years, we've stayed close because we often engage in similar activities, although we're quite different. I'm more outgoing, outspoken, and carefree, while @PERSON1 is conservative and can take things too seriously. However, our differences balance each other out. After finals week ended, @PERSON1 and I planned a sleepover. We needed to relax and have some time to ourselves. When I got home from school, I called her and asked when she wanted to hang out. She suggested @NUM2, and I was excited. I quickly gathered my things, including my toothbrush, pillow, pajamas, and blanket. My dad dropped me off at her place. When I arrived, @PERSON1 greeted me with a big smile and led me to her basement, where she had set out a variety of junk food on an old pool table. There were chips, cookies, sodas, candy, chocolate, and pizza. We feasted for almost an hour and then lay on the floor to recover. We laughed at the commercials on her big - screen @CAPS7 and then started talking about our finals. @PERSON1 bragged that she had done well and would get all A's, as she has since middle school. I said I thought I did pretty well too but wasn't sure about a @NUM3. Later, we moved to the couch to watch an old scary movie and the top @NUM5 music videos of the week. By @NUM2 in the @TIME1, we were tired and fell asleep. The next @TIME1, when I woke up, @PERSON1 was sitting in the corner with a folded piece of paper. I asked what was up, and she threw the crumpled paper at me. It was her report card. She had all A's except for a @CAPS13 in her @CAPS15 class. She was very upset, but when I asked if she was crying over a @CAPS13, she looked at me and then burst out laughing. We both laughed because she felt silly for crying over it. @PERSON1 and I are perfect best friends. We balance each other out. I tell her to relax, and she tells me to focus. We should not take small things too seriously and need to find a balance between work and play.

Laughter is an essential element in any relationship, whether it's a friendship, a romantic relationship, or a work - related one. It prevents people from becoming overly tense and unapproachable. Everyone needs laughter in their lives, as it can cheer them up during difficult times. Laughing every day can bring happiness, even when one is in a bad mood. For those who are suicidal, a bit of laughter can make a significant difference. Laughing with friends or loved ones is a wonderful experience, and it's also nice to see others smile and laugh. After finals week, a friend and I planned a sleepover to relax. When I got home from school, I called her to confirm the time. Then I gathered my things and went to her place. Her basement was filled with junk food, and we had a great time eating and laughing at commercials. We also talked about our finals. The next day, I found her upset because she had received a @CAPS13 on her report card, despite getting all A's otherwise. At first, I was a bit amused by her reaction, but then we both ended up laughing at the situation. In conclusion, laughter is a powerful force that can bring people together and make life more enjoyable. It helps us deal with stress and find joy in the simplest things. We should all make an effort to laugh more often and share that happiness with others.

I believe that laughter and a sense of humor are common traits among people, and everyone loves to share them. Among young teenage girls, laughter is an infectious and wonderful gift. It represents the purest form of joy and is what brings people together, being both the start and the end of friendship and unity. Laughter can lift the spirits of those in need. A simple laugh can turn a bad day around. In a world full of dread and sadness, the kindness and generosity of laughter are some of the few good things left. Even in difficult situations like poverty, depression, and oppression, laughter can briefly wash away worries and fill people with warmth. @PERSON1 and I have been best friends since we were ten. Laughter has always been the strongest part of our friendship. We have a talent for making each other laugh, even when we're angry or sad. We believe that separately, we're only a little funny, but together, we can make anyone laugh. We use this ability to cheer each other up on bad days. My first impression of @PERSON1 was when she stomped to the neighborhood park to yell at her sister, whom I was playing with. At first, I didn't like her. But after going to her house with her sister, we discovered we had much in common and were only four months apart. Our friendship was rocky at the beginning, with a lot of fighting and arguing. We would make dumb comments instead of apologizing. For example, she once told me I couldn't hear her because there was a big bug in my ear. Now, we look back on those incidents and laugh. When we were @NUM1 - year - olds, our friendship was held together by our childish banter. Now, almost @NUM2, we rarely fight and always laugh, making the most of our time together by poking fun at each other. @PERSON1 has a gift for making anything funny. Laughter is a necessity in our friendship, keeping it strong. I can't imagine what our friendship would be like without it. If laughter were not a part of daily life, the human race would be dull and unhappy. Laughter heals people and gives the feeling that everything will be okay. It's a natural and healthy gift that we should cherish. I strive to laugh every day and make at least one other person laugh. A life without laughter is not a life worth living, as it is the key to happiness and connection.

Laughter is truly one of life's greatest gifts. Have you ever laughed so hard that you cried, couldn't breathe, or couldn't make a sound? I'm the kind of person who can burst into laughter at something stupid and not even know why I started. Sometimes, I laugh so hard that nothing comes out at all. Laughter has a remarkable effect on a person's heart. It changes the way you feel and act. It's incredibly contagious and happens all around us every day. There's no age limit for laughter; it can happen to anyone, young or old. One time, @CAPS2, @CAPS3, @CAPS4, and I stayed up until three in the @TIME1. We were so delirious and crazy that we acted like mad people. We have a relationship where we can laugh at almost anything. To keep ourselves awake, we drank lots of soda and ate sugary foods. We made up songs, danced around @CAPS2's house, and it felt like we laughed for hours. I laughed until tears streamed from my eyes and I couldn't catch my breath. When the laughter turns silent, it's even funnier because the person can't control it. They rock back and forth with a silly expression on their face, making no noise at all. Have you ever laughed for what seems like forever? After such a long bout of laughter, it feels as if the sun is warming your heart and soul. When I laugh, I feel all the happiness and emotion flowing through my body. It's one of the greatest feelings in the world. It's wonderful to sit back with a friend or a group of friends and enjoy shared laughter. Even when you're feeling down, a good laugh can lift your spirits. No matter what mood I'm in, when I hear someone laughing, it's hard not to join in. Laughter affects our daily lives. I bet you can't go a day without hearing someone laugh or laughing yourself. I probably laugh about five hundred times a day, if not more. I love hearing people laugh; it brightens my mood and my day. Laughter is very important and beneficial for relationships. Imagine a world without laughter; it would be so boring. My advice is to laugh like you've heard the funniest thing in the world, like there's no tomorrow. Don't care what others think. You'll feel much better after a tear - inducing, breathless, silent but therapeutic laugh. Laughter truly is the shortest distance between people.

Laughter serves as an expression of delight, fun, or a reaction to a joke. It is a universal human behavior that brings significant benefits to our lives and occurs regularly. Without laughter, we would struggle to showcase our happy and outgoing sides, and our lives would be filled with nothing but frowning. Frowning is known to cause more wrinkles as it engages more facial muscles.  For me, laughter is an all - day affair. The @CAPS1 show, my friends, family, and horses are the main reasons my frown turns upside down. You might think horses can't smile or talk, but they have their own unique ways of showing personalities that make you laugh. They are all smart, yet can be clumsy or goofy at times, much like little brothers or sisters.  One particular memory is firmly etched in my mind. It was a mid - day on @DATE1 at the beach on the @ORGANIZATION1. I was with a friend, and we had our two horses saddled and ready. The moment we saw the waves crashing on the shore and smelled the salt in the air, both we and our horses felt a rush of energy.  Once on the sand, we galloped side by side, with the wind whistling past our ears like a moving train. The horses' heads were all pointed towards the ocean. When we reached the water, the horses pranced and danced like young foals. They walked deep into the water until we were drenched, and then, as the next wave rushed in, we'd swerve around to beat it to the shore.  After about five hours of exploring caves, sand dunes, and looking at starfish, we were exhausted and decided to end the day. It was around dinner time, so we ate while watching the sunset, concluding a perfect day at the beach. We put the horses back in the trailer, and before closing the door, I gave my horse a gentle pat on the neck. As I was about to leave, my horse turned its head and gave me a nudge, as if saying "thanks for the good time". Driving home, I knew it was a perfect day because of all the laughter. My face even ached a bit from smiling so much.

Starting off, naming two @NUM1 @DATE1 - old boys @ORGANIZATION1 is already comical. These are the names of my identical twin cousins. I must admit they are among the funniest kids I've ever known. My uncle, while a hard - working man, doesn't seem to have the best sense of humor, as evidenced by how he named his children.  Occasionally, my mom helps him out by taking the twins for a while since they can be quite a handful. Weekends are ideal for having them over, mainly because of my hateful step - siblings who dislike me, my brother, my sister, and even my mom. The tense atmosphere at home is not healthy, so having these energetic @NUM1 @DATE1 - olds around liven things up and makes us laugh as a family.  It was @DATE1 in @DATE2 when @CAPS7 was home, and we were building an extension to our house when the twins came over. My mom was extremely frustrated with their high energy levels and seemed on the verge of losing her temper. My step - dad @PERSON1 needed to go to @PERSON2's for nails and child locks, and I decided to go with him. I thought taking the twins would relieve my mom from their noise for a bit.  We loaded into the car, and I drove on the highway. I was entertained by the twins in the back seat, playing with ponies and laughing at people at red lights. We sang songs like "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" and the @ORGANIZATION2's until we reached @PERSON2's parking lot.  One twin found it hilarious to run down the aisles and hide behind lower - shelf items, while the other enjoyed pretending to be @ORGANIZATION1 and confusing @CAPS7. Eventually, they became too rowdy. @LOCATION1 and I caught them and strapped them into the @PERSON2's cart seat - belts, but it didn't solve the problem as well as we hoped.  We continued our search for child locks and found them in aisle @NUM4. There was a large man in front of the items. By "large", I don't mean muscular or tall; he seemed to watch too many @CAPS1 shows and have too many favorite snacks. He had long, sandy - blond hair, wore a dark - purple @CAPS2 die shirt and slip - on sandals.  One of the twins loudly said, "@CAPS3 cow! Look at that lady! She's so huge!" and burst into laughter, with the other twin agreeing. "@CAPS4! She's as big as our whole car!" I panicked and tried to make them quiet, but they ignored me. They were then distracted by a man on a ladder who was laughing with them. They then gasped and exclaimed, "@CAPS5 she's as big as a fire truck!" The man turned and glared at me. I apologized multiple times and started to take the boys away.  The man on the ladder hit a button, and the ladder made a loud beeping sound. The boys screamed in fear, shouting, "@CAPS6 run as fast as you can hurry! She's backing up and she's going to squish you on the floor!" Everyone laughed, including the man they were teasing. I was embarrassed and took them to the car to wait for @PERSON1.  I tried to explain to the boys in the car that only big trucks beep when backing up, but they didn't listen. @PERSON1 came out jogging with the nails, child locks, and a big smile on his face. I thought about what had happened and started laughing again. When I got home and told my mom, she laughed too, and I laughed even harder. That day, despite the chaos, was filled with so much laughter that it was worth it.

Meeting new people is always an interesting experience. As the saying goes, friends come and go, but true friends stay. I remember the first time I met @PERSON1. To me, she was not just a friend; I knew I wanted to build a life with her. People often say that love is a myth, but I believe it's real. Love comes from above and stays forever.  When I first spoke to her, it felt like God was guiding me, telling me she was the one. I saw that her heart was broken, and I knew I had to save her from further pain. Looking into her eyes, I could feel her pain, and I told her, "Your heart won't be broken because I'll give you mine." I expressed my feelings to her, saying, "You're the one I've always wanted and needed. You're like a tattoo on my heart, the apple of my eye. I want to stand with you on a mountain and show you that I'm different from other guys. I'm faithful and will always be by your side."  I also told her how much I loved every aspect of her, from her eyes and smile to her personality. I asked her to take a chance on me, knowing she had been through a lot. To my delight, she said yes. She was overjoyed, as if her dream had finally come true. She found a guy who was faithful, honest, and would never lie or cheat.  I told her she was my super - human, and she said I had changed her life. She had also changed mine. I told her that my heart belonged only to her, and if she didn't have it, my heart would be meaningless. I promised to always keep her warm, day and night. I said that all my wishes had come true because I finally had her by my side.  I shared with her how other girls had played with my heart in the past, and I had been searching for an honest, faithful, and true girl. I was so happy to say that I had found her in @PERSON1. I promised her that she would never be sad again and that I would always be just one phone call away.  She was extremely happy when I told her she was my paradise, my whole world. Our love, I believe, will never die. It will stand strong, reaching for the sky, until the sun stops shining. I'm crazy about her, and she's crazy about me. She holds the key to my heart, and I finally understand what true love feels like. She has turned all my bad days into good ones, and I will never break her heart.

People often claim that laughter is a crucial part of a relationship, but I was initially unsure. My grandmother, however, firmly believes that laughter has played a significant role in her relationship with my grandfather.  She was @NUM1 and @CAPS1 was @NUM2 when they first met. Everyone predicted their relationship wouldn't last, but they persevered. My grandmother said she felt like singing whenever she heard his name. She felt that all her problems would disappear when she was with him, and just thinking about him would make her smile and laugh.  I often wonder if what they had was love. I think it was. My grandmother seems so happy when she talks about him, but I'm still not entirely sure if laughter was the sole factor that kept them together for so long. She once said, "@CAPS1 wasn't the smartest, but he always knew how to make me laugh."  My grandmother asked me what I thought when I saw two couples laughing and having a good time. The first thing that comes to mind is that they know how to enjoy life and aren't easily bothered. She believes that if you can't make the other person laugh, you might not have a fulfilling relationship.  When my grandparents are angry with each other, it doesn't last long because my grandfather always knows how to make her laugh. I now understand why my grandmother fell in love with my grandfather. In a relationship, being able to put a smile on the other person's face is essential.  My grandmother was right. Laughter does play a huge part in their relationship. They always manage to turn difficult situations around with jokes and funny actions. I can never be mad at them because they know so many ways to make me laugh. Laughter is what holds our family together, and it clearly has a significant impact on their long - lasting relationship.

Laughter is the best medicine" is a well - known phrase, and it's absolutely true. There have been days when I felt like life was going terribly wrong, but then one of my best friends would say something hilarious, and I'd laugh so hard that I'd almost wet my pants, my eyes would water, and my sides would cramp. I'd even fall on the floor, unable to make a sound. I sometimes think that even if I were in a coma, they could still make me laugh.  One particular day, @DATE1, @CAPS1, and I were in an extremely giggly mood. We staggered to @CAPS1's house, flushed and giddy because everything seemed so funny. You know those moments when you and your friends are so tickled by each other that just a glance makes you burst into laughter again? Well, we experienced that feeling for hours. I'm pretty sure I developed new abdominal muscles from laughing so hard.  When we got to her house, we tried to be serious as we had some homework to do. But after all that laughing, we were starving. @CAPS1 told @ORGANIZATION1 and me that we could have some cereal. Usually, milk and cereal are just ordinary, but that day, the milk was extraordinary. @ORGANIZATION1 exclaimed how good it was, and I was also blown away by its taste. When I asked @CAPS1 what kind of milk it was, her curious expression made us all laugh even more.  At one point, @CAPS1 peed her pants. It wasn't a little bit; it was a full - on accident. I don't even remember what I said to make her laugh so hard. She was red - faced and holding onto the counter, trying not to laugh. When I realized what was happening, I started laughing at her, which only made her laugh harder. She then waddled down the hall to the bathroom like a penguin. @ORGANIZATION1 also laughed at the sight of her.  I love my friends because we always laugh at each other and ourselves. @CAPS1 is always there to laugh at my jokes, and @ORGANIZATION1 is really good at coming up with them. I truly enjoy laughing, especially with my best friends. Laughter has the power to turn a bad day into a great one, and those moments with my friends are some of the best memories I have.

One day, while skateboarding with my friend, I got very angry and wanted to quit. His mom tried to persuade me to keep going. She said I would never be good enough at skating, yet she also mentioned that I had improved more than some people she knew. This made me feel better, and from then on, I started skateboarding every day. Whenever I recall that day, I still laugh. Skating can be enjoyable in numerous ways. People skate for fun and for competitions. There are different skating styles, and everyone has their own way. There are many types of skateboards, and riders use them differently. Sometimes, I laugh at some skateboarders because of their skating styles. Skating is a great activity that brings joy and a sense of improvement, and I'm glad I didn't give up on it.

Laughter"  It is commonly believed that a good relationship is founded on trust. Throughout my life, I've often heard this view. However, as I've grown and begun to think independently, I've come up with my own survival guide for good relationships. While trust is indeed important, I've discovered that laughter is equally crucial, not only for initiating a relationship but also for keeping it vibrant.  My mother played a significant role in helping me understand this concept. My mom and I share an exceptional bond and a deep understanding of each other, which many of the girls I know don't have with their mothers. I consider myself extremely fortunate. Like all families, we've had our tough times, but we can always laugh them off and start anew. This realization made me appreciate the quote, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people."  Although having a strong bond with my mom is of utmost importance to me, our relationship hasn't always been smooth. From around the age of ten to thirteen, I was reluctant to show my emotions and preferred to stay silent. Admiring my mom for her strength and beauty, I was worried that she might see me as a disappointment. I was afraid to reveal my true self to her. When she joked with me, I took things too seriously, and during our minor disputes, I thought she would hate me forever. Looking back, I realize how silly I was, but I'm grateful for those experiences as they made our relationship stronger.  One night after dinner, my mom told me it was my turn to do the dishes. I completely forgot and went to my room to listen to music and eventually fell asleep. My mom came into my room, upset and frustrated. She said, “Why did you ignore me? The dishes need to be done now.” I got out of bed without a word and headed to the kitchen. She followed me and said, “It's okay that you forgot. I'm not mad.” I still remained silent, relieved when I turned around and saw she had left.  After I finished the dishes, she pulled me into my room. She looked worried and explained the relationship she had with her own mother, which she hoped to have with me. She told me how they would laugh together at silly things and promised to stop arguing, take a deep breath, and then laugh it off. I was curious and asked why they did that. She replied, “Laughter is the best cure for any sad feeling or bad day, as grandma would always say.” She then tickled me and joked around, and for the first time, I wasn't nervous and spoke my mind. As we sat there, laughing until we fell asleep, I knew our relationship would change for the better.  Now, at fifteen, I can confidently say that my mom is my best and truest friend. Our ability to overcome difficulties and laugh off stressful situations makes me believe I can face anything. I've truly grasped the meaning of the saying, “Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.”

Laughter is an integral part of my life. If you're interested in a story about laughter, well, my life is filled with it. I even joke that if it weren't for laughing, I wouldn't have the six - pack I have now. Have you ever thought that when one person makes another laugh, they often become close friends, maybe even best friends? My boyfriend, @PERSON1, is my best friend.  I've only known him for about a year, but a lot can happen in that time. You can meet new people, build relationships, or even move away from them. @PERSON1 and I do everything together and are always laughing, either at each other or at other things.  One late @DATE1 @TIME1, he was walking me home as he always did. There was a field with extremely tall grass beside our path. Suddenly, he pretended to be pulled into the grass. I screamed as loudly as I could. Then he called my name in a creepy voice, inviting me to the grass. Out of curiosity, I walked towards the tall grass. Laughter is the key to the soul." Whether you're having the worst or the best day of your life, laughing can always improve the situation. One day, I was sitting in @CAPS2 class, extremely bored. There are numerous joys in life. Some are more significant than others, and some are so obvious that it would be foolish not to notice them. Have you ever sat on your porch or stared out the window to watch the sunrise, reflecting on your life, its unique qualities, all the great memories, shared laughs, sorrows, pain, love, and hate? It's not surprising that most people have done this and wondered if they could change things, how they would do it, or if they'd leave their life as it is, feeling complete and having no regrets.  For all the tears I've shed and the pain I've endured, there's always been a laugh to overcome the sadness. Sometimes, I sit and ponder my life. I've realized that no matter how hard you plan your life, there will always be unexpected things or people. All you can do is hope for the best and prepare for the worst.  It's not difficult to be happy. Just keep an open mind and a light heart, and you'll find yourself laughing with the world and enjoying your time on this amazing planet, @LOCATION1. So, listen to your parents or the person you admire most.  There are many things that keep me going, like my boyfriend and my love for animals. But the most important thing isn't just one thing; it's a combination of things such as love, laughter, new beginnings, old endings, a bright new path (you just need to take it), the endless possibilities of the universe, and the idea that there might be other planets with life, perhaps even intelligent life.  It's easy to find reasons to live and even easier to find reasons to die. Hopefully, you'll focus on the reasons to live. I remember a time when I was so down that I thought I'd never be happy and that I didn't fit in with the world's confusing aspects. I felt like I was at the end of my path. But then, as I sat by an old road and looked at the stars, I thought about all the things I'd miss if I ended my life. I thought about naming my children, getting married, and whether our love would last.  After that evening, I decided to continue my life and become a better person. I want a bright future with a romantic love story to tell my children. I also want to find peace in a noisy world, help animals co - exist with us instead of pushing them aside or abusing their rights, and solve the pollution problem that humans have contributed to.  Even though I'm just one person, I believe that what I do or say can make an impact. If I want to look back and laugh, I need to do my part to make this planet a shared and healthy place.

In the end, I believe that @PERSON1 and @ORGANIZATION1 will be friends for a long time, and perhaps in the future, their relationship could evolve further. Only time will tell.

I never thought that laughter could be the key to starting a conversation with a stranger, but @CAPS4 proved me wrong. Just sharing a laugh with someone can lead to a new acquaintance. At first, I couldn't hear what they were saying, but as we got closer, I heard a hilarious comment. I couldn't help but start laughing. One of his friends noticed me laughing and thought I was laughing at him. He asked me, and I explained that I had accidentally overheard their conversation. He then started laughing too and said, "That was funny, wasn't it?" I replied, "Yes, it was. I didn't know you made jokes like that."  We continued talking, and I started laughing again. He asked what he said, and I told him I was just remembering his earlier comment, which was really funny. I couldn't forget what he said, probably because our meeting was so unexpected. I had never met a guy by laughing first, and I thought it was a great way to start a conversation.  Laughing with someone shows that you're interested in their topic and understand them. We had a great conversation and talked about my vacations. I told him that I love coming to @LOCATION1 every year and that I sometimes wish I could live there because it's so calm. He agreed with me as he knew what it was like to live in @LOCATION1 but had no idea about other places.  As our conversation continued, we noticed that our group had left us. We laughed about it and went to find them. They were still shopping and didn't seem to notice we were gone. From that day on, I realized that laughter can break the ice and create a connection. Now, whenever I go to @LOCATION1, I know I have a new friend, and I believe I can make more friends by simply sharing a laugh.

As I sat in the car, eagerly awaiting the moment to meet my best friend and the man I'm in love with, nervous laughter bubbled up inside me. As our black rental sedan pulled up to where he was waiting outside his family's home, my nerves intensified. What if he wasn't who I thought he was? What if he didn't like me? I replied, "Hello, @PERSON2," my stomach fluttering with butterflies.  He reached out and gently took my hand, asking, "How was the drive?" I answered, "Long, and nerve-wracking," my nervous laughter returning. He said, "But you're here now, and I'm very happy you are," with a warm smile.  For the rest of the car ride to the restaurant, our conversation flowed effortlessly. We were two guys in love, experiencing this new feeling together, and we were incredibly happy. It also helped that he was holding my hand under the table.  After dinner and dessert, we went to the nearby mall. My mom and brother went one way, and @PERSON2 and I went another. We bought some clothes and ended up in my favorite bookstore, @ORGANIZATION3's. In the young adult fiction section, @PERSON2 stared at me. When I asked why, he said, "You just look very... In your element." I pretended to be confused, and he just smiled and took my hand again.  He pulled me closer and asked if he could be a little forward. I nodded yes, and he kissed me gently on the lips. I blushed and started to giggle after our lips parted. He raised an eyebrow, and I knew what he was thinking. I said, "That felt fantastic," touching my lips. He simply said, "Good," and kissed me again. He told me he loved my laugh, and I felt on top of the world. I was truly in love, and it was the best feeling I had ever experienced.  Since then, we've been together, and whenever I think about that day, I can't help but giggle happily. Laughter was the bridge that connected us, and it has made our relationship stronger than ever.

Fourth period in freshman year was the highlight of my entire freshman year. Most people called him @LOCATION1, but I simply called him @CAPS1. Another fun moment was when we were doing example problems on our own. We didn't have a proper science laboratory in our regular classroom, so the other science teacher, @CAPS15, let us use her classroom for a school @CAPS14 as her class had an online report to do. @CAPS1 banned me from using matches because his nickname for me was @CAPS16 - @CAPS17. On the final day, a bunch of glass test tubes were broken. When I asked what happened, he initially blamed a classmate but started laughing when he looked at me, giving himself away. After he finished giving notes and the assignment, some friends of @CAPS3 @CAPS19 asked him if he was a swimmer and if he shaved his legs. I often wonder why people laugh. People laugh when something is funny, when situations are awkward, or when they're embarrassed or offended. Every year since I moved here six and @DATE1, my two cousins, sisters, and I have gone "cheese ball caroling" with our grandparents around @CAPS1 time. On the twenty - first of @DATE2, we take turns going secret @LOCATION1 shopping with a grandparent while making cheese balls by hand. After all five of us have gone, we wrap the cheese balls, add a ribbon, and practice our carols for the evening.  We always make a list before caroling. The list includes the names of the houses we'll visit, the number of cheese balls to deliver to each house, and the song we'll sing. Usually, there are about twenty - five to thirty people on the list, all of whom are family members, close friends, or colleagues of our grandparents.  Last year was the first time we caroled without my older sister, who had gone to college the @DATE3 before. At first, it didn't seem different, but as the day went on, I felt the pressure building. With my sister and grandpa gone, the responsibility seemed to fall on me as the oldest grand - kid.  When we started, I tried to relax and have fun. My grandma asked me to add a name to the list. I asked my grandma to confirm, and it was indeed the same family.

Laughter is the essence of true happiness; all one needs to do is laugh to embrace it. I recall being the new student in the @NUM1 grade. It was a brand - new school with a new bus and new everything. I had no idea where anything was. Being the new kid is tough; you often get mocked and may not fit in. That was my story - I never truly fit in.  One bright, sunny day with not a cloud in the sky, I was walking up the stairs to my class. As I climbed, I tripped and fell backward. Afterward, a girl named @CAPS2 approached me and told me I wasn't the only one who wore character underpants. We laughed uncontrollably that day, just remembering me falling down the stairs. Being the new kid could be embarrassing, but I'd been in such situations countless times, so it didn't bother me as much as others thought.  @CAPS2 and I became great friends. We laughed all the time, like when she fell into the ice - cold water at the park or when I fell down the stairs. To this day, we still talk about it; it's an unforgettable memory. And yes, it was pretty funny when my character underpants showed.  In conclusion, the quote "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people" holds true. One must have a good laugh to start the day right. If you don't laugh throughout the day, something's amiss. Just because you're growing older doesn't mean you should abandon your ability to laugh. Laughing is the part of the day when you can be carefree. So, what's your funny story?

The first time I saw @ORGANIZATION1, she completely captivated me. She was my other half, and every moment we spent together was perfect. Her every word made me laugh; she truly was my better half.  I still remember seeing her in @CAPS1. The town was nicknamed @CAPS1 @CAPS4 hell because it was in the middle of nowhere. My parents had retired a few months prior and were searching for a cozy retirement home away from the big cities, closer to the beautiful eastern @LOCATION2 mountains with their snowy peaks and stunning landscapes.  We took a trailer and stayed there for about a week. That trailer was a nightmare; every time we stopped, I had to set everything up, even if we weren't going to use it. It was a two - hour process, and after doing it so many times, I got bored.  Finding a great house to stay in that town was easy. The houses were all amazing, homemade by the town's men. They were incredible two - story oak houses that seemed strong enough to withstand a tornado with only minor damage. But we had to sell our current house first to afford it, so we put it on the "@CAPS4 @CAPS5 @CAPS6" and went back to the trailer.  I was incredibly bored during the remaining @NUM1 days. I rode over to see what was going on and started talking to a guy named @CAPS8. He told me they'd just returned from a youth - group get - together on the snake, where they'd gone tubing and cliff - jumping. I was in awe; it seemed crazy for a youth group. But that's how they did things in @CAPS1. They didn't just have picnics; they did wild things I'd never done, partly because I'm not that daring and partly because I'd never had the chance.  Before they left, they invited me on their nature hike up the mountain. I was thrilled as I love hiking. The next morning at @TIME1, I was excited and ready. I had my permission slip signed and jumped on my dad's bike. I arrived at the youth administrator's house just in time for a protein shake. We drove to the mountain, and at the base, there were about @NUM3 - @NUM4 people in hiking gear. That's when I met @LOCATION1. She was gorgeous, and I was immediately attracted to her. We started climbing and talking; we got along so well. Her laugh made me extremely happy. She was my other half, and all I can remember is her amazing laugh.

The @CAPS3 story is about a time when I had a rather unfortunate yet funny experience. About four or five years ago, on a hot day, I went to a friend's house for the @TIME1. My friend and I wanted to have fun and stay cool, so we went to the garage, found a sprinkler, and put it under the trampoline. This made the trampoline wet and slippery.  We started jumping on the trampoline. My friend was jumping higher than me, and I was losing my bounce. When he came down at the same time as me, his greater bounce and weight made me bounce much higher than usual. When I came back down, I landed on my back, and the angle on the trampoline sent me flying off.  As I was bounced off, I thought I'd get hurt. I'd rather have a few scratches than land on dog manure, but that's exactly what happened. I landed on a pile of it, and it stank up my shirt terribly. After taking off my shirt, I started jumping again and jumped for the whole day.  I don't regret it because it made everyone, including me, have a good laugh. The @CAPS3 story is a testament to the power of laughter. Even when something bad happens, it can turn into a source of fun in the end.

Have you ever been so scared that you couldn't sleep all night? Were you with a group of @NUM1 friends at the time? But when @PERSON4 got up to use the bathroom, the @CAPS25 turned off, all the lights in the house went out, and we saw shadows on the living - room walls. @CAPS13 started crying, @LOCATION2 complained, @PERSON4 wouldn't go to the bathroom, and I freaked out. After all the commotion, my parents didn't wake up, and we went to my room to continue talking about the @CAPS23 stories. Laughter and a sense of exuberance are crucial in any good relationship. Being able to share moments of joy with someone close is a sign of comfort and can strengthen friendships. Your true self often shines through your sense of humor.  Two years ago, in @PERSON1's seventh - grade math class at @ORGANIZATION1, I was selected to be part of the @ORGANIZATION2, along with just three other classmates. Being in the @ORGANIZATION2 meant we'd teach ourselves @CAPS1 - @CAPS2 using only textbooks, while @PERSON1 taught the rest of the class easier math. It was like an elite club. As immature seventh - graders, we took advantage of this great opportunity. I quickly befriended @PERSON4, @PERSON3, and @CAPS3. @PERSON4 and I were already friends, but working in the @ORGANIZATION2 brought us even closer. To this day, @PERSON4 is one of my best friends, and I still keep in touch with the other two.  We were all different. @PERSON3 was popular, @CAPS3 hung out with smart kids into chess and reading, and @PERSON4 and I were just ordinary. However, we shared a sick sense of humor and intelligence.  We found the self - taught work extremely easy. We breezed through the book with no questions. One day after lunch, as we walked into @PERSON1's math class, I complained, "@PERSON4, I don't feel like doing math @DATE2. I'm exhausted." She replied, "@CAPS6 neither. Let's just pretend to work." We went to the back table where @CAPS3 and @PERSON3 were sitting. They had their books out but looked bored.  I lied, saying, "@CAPS8 uh, I was talking to @LOCATION1 @TIME1, and he said we don't have to work @DATE2. We can just hang out." @CAPS3 and @PERSON3 caught on and grinned. @PERSON3 took out a brown paper bag from her backpack and offered us food. I grabbed a miniature chocolate pie. While eating it, I dipped my finger in the chocolate and wiped it on the window behind @CAPS6. @PERSON4 noticed and started chuckling. She exclaimed, "@CAPS10, what's that?!" loud enough for the class to hear. @PERSON1 and a few classmates glanced over but went back to the lesson. It wasn't really funny, but we all started giggling.  As the laughter died down, @PERSON3 said, "@CAPS11 guys, I had a crazy dream @TIME2. I went to a @DATE1 camp, and @PERSON2 was a camp counselor in khaki pants and a white shirt with blue pinstripes, and he had a clipboard!" We stared blankly and then burst out laughing again. It was funny because @PERSON2 often substituted for our teachers and always wore that outfit.  Our laughter stopped, and we sat in silence. Suddenly, @CAPS3 leaned back in his squeaky swivel

People often claim that laughter has numerous benefits. However, in my view, laughter isn't always the best thing as it can carry various meanings. When I think of laughter, I associate it with smiles, happiness, and memories. Yet, there's one memory of laughter that doesn't fit this positive association.  I pleaded with my friend's mother, saying, "I really don't wanna be here. I don't know if I can stay and tell him this. Please let me go back home." She replied, "You need to do this, honey. It's for the best." At that point, I always thought she knew best, but now I wasn't so certain.  I sat patiently, holding back tears, waiting for my friend's father to return home. I knew he was at the bar and silently thanked him for giving me time to think. I was supposed to tell him how I felt about his constant alcohol - drinking. Every time I went there, he was either drunk or on his way to being drunk. I was scared, both for his health and because I thought I might be the reason for his drinking. But I was getting older and needed to express my thoughts and feelings.  While lost in these thoughts, he stormed through the door. When I looked up at my friend's drunk father, my heart dropped. I burst into tears as my friend's mother held me in her arms. She soothed me, saying, "It's alright." My friend's father looked at me without recognition and went into another room.  I cautiously watched him through the open doorway. He was no longer the man my friend's mother had married; he had become a monster. I couldn't stand it anymore. I went to the room where my friend's mother was waiting, her eyes full of worry, and said, "Let's go home."  On the way home, I sobbed until my shirt was streaked with tears. The car ride was silent, and the sadness hung thick in the air. I barely slept that night.  The next morning, as the sun shone on my face, I felt confident and ready to go back and confess my feelings to my friend's father. When we arrived at his house, nervousness rushed through me. I wobbled up to the door and knocked. His non -chalant greeting made me upset.  I walked in with confidence and asked him to sit down. I was glad to catch him in a rare non - drunk moment. I basically screamed at him, "We really need to talk. I feel you're making a huge mistake by drinking. I know you're addicted, and there are risks in stopping, but you're also endangering your health!" I poured out my heart as new tears welled up.  When I finished, my friend's father just sat there with a blank look and laughed. He said, "Your mother told you to tell me this. Don't worry. Your friend doesn't know what she's talking about." I was so angry that I screamed, "You don't even know me! You don't care about me!" and then stormed out.  In the living room, I looked at my friend's mother, and she knew I wanted to leave. The car ride home was again filled with silence. Thinking about how laughter is usually a great thing, I cried because this time, laughter didn't mean happiness; it meant tears.

One day, my parents gathered around me and said, "We've got something to tell you." I already knew what was coming as I had noticed the signs. When they went into another room, it wasn't for a good time; they were getting a divorce, and the time to tell me had arrived.  As they sat around me, I knew I was about to hear something I wasn't prepared for. The words "We are getting a divorce" rang in my head like wedding bells, but this was the exact opposite of a happy occasion.  When I looked at my mother, I could tell she had been crying. Her eyes, which used to have a blue - gray mixture, were now red and irritated. It broke my heart to see her like that. Meanwhile, my dad sat on the couch near me, his head buried in his hands. I could tell he was thinking about how their love had gone downhill, leaving him with resentment and anger towards my mother. The woman he loved was now his enemy.  At the age of seven, I couldn't fully understand what was happening to our family. I knew one parent would move away, and I wouldn't have both of them tuck me into bed at night. But I just couldn't understand why this had to happen.  I also thought about my little brother, who was only four. How could my parents explain this to him? If I was confused, he must have been completely lost.  Seeing our family fall apart made me want to cry and run away from all the troubles at home. If I had three wishes from a genie, I would use them all to save my parents' relationship.  Crying seemed easier than listening to my parents say, "It's not your fault. Don't blame yourself. This is between your father and me." I didn't think their words made me feel better. Their love for each other was gone, and my hope of them getting back together was fading fast, just like the rainforests in [LOCATION1]. More importantly, my home and my heart were broken, and I didn't think anything could fix them.  Just when I felt like the world was crashing down on me, my mother said something I'd never forget: "If you feel like crying, laugh. Remember all the good times we spent as a family." Memories started flooding back - like when my dad jumped into the pile of leaves we raked, or when my mom and I made burnt sugar cookies in winter that still made the house warm. And especially their wedding, which changed our lives forever.  I started to laugh and then cry. My parents were confused about my sudden change of emotion. They asked, "What's wrong?" Then I realized that even though our family wouldn't be together all the time, we would still laugh. When someone slipped on a piece of paper, it would still be funny.  From that day on, I believed in my mother's words: "If you feel like crying, laugh." It told me it's okay to be sad, but as long as there's laughter in life, everything will be alright. I was proud of my mom for handling the situation so well. If it weren't for her, I would have kept crying and never thought about all the happy times we had. So, we should always take a moment each day to remember the funny moments.

Laughter is a feeling of pure happiness. When you're laughing, nothing else matters, and all your worries and stress fade away, leaving you with your true, happy self.  Have you ever had moments when everything seemed overwhelming, and then a friend said something that made you laugh? After laughing, you might start crying because it felt so good. Or have you laughed so hard that you fell to the floor and couldn't get up for what seemed like hours, but later forgot what was so funny?  Laughter is magical, second only to love. These two emotions seem to go hand in hand. When you love someone - whether it's a boyfriend/girlfriend, friends, or family - you know how to make them laugh, cheer them up, and have fun with them, which brings you closer together.  When I'm with my six friends, we mostly laugh. We laugh at anything slightly funny, and it strengthens our bond. We'll remain friends even after high school, no matter how far apart our colleges are because we've shared so many happy memories.  Laughter is crucial in a relationship. We trust each other and can share our most important secrets. This story explains how we became so close.  One day, after the school dance, our room was filled with brightly colored dresses, high heels, open soda cans, and chip bags. The air smelled of nail polish, perfume, and deodorant. Laughter and giggles filled the room, along with the occasional squeal.  We had all dressed up for the dance but quickly changed into sweatpants and baggy t - shirts. Our makeup was smeared, and our hair was falling. Yet, we didn't care. We looked past each other's appearances and just had fun.  None of us had dates at the dance, but we still had a great time. We gossiped about the people we saw, the dancing, and even how we marked our cups.  It was late at night, and everyone was exhausted but kept themselves awake with caffeine and sugar. Maybe it was because we always had so much to talk about or because we enjoyed each other's company.  I suggested taking a picture of the six of us. One of my friends, [PERSON1], ran upstairs to get an old instant - print camera. We squeezed into a corner of the bed to take the picture.  As we took the photos, the bed suddenly broke. We were all in shock at first, but then we burst into hysterics. Even [PERSON1]'s mom was laughing. We were a big pile of laughter.  The first picture showed us smiling, and the second was taken just as the bed broke, capturing our shocked faces. This incident not only brought us physically closer but also strengthened our friendship.

Laughter is an important part of our daily lives. Humans enjoy laughing and making others laugh. This reminds me of a funny experience during a writing test.  The test required me to write about one of four topics, all of which were extremely vague and uninteresting. I found it quite ironic that I had to choose from these unappealing options, and for some strange reason, I found this situation amusing. I sat there silently laughing at my predicament.  Then it dawned on me that one of the topics was about laughter. I decided to write about myself laughing at the irony of my situation. The topic's vagueness worked in my favor as it didn't specify that the laugh had to be audible or what kind of laugh it should be. So, I thought a silent laugh at irony would be just as valid.  As I wrote about myself laughing at the fact that I had to write about myself laughing, I found the task so silly that I started laughing again. However, I worried that the grader might not find it as amusing as I did, which could affect my grade. But this possibility only made the situation more ironic and amusing.  You might think I'm easily amused, and well, I am. I find beauty in laughter because it's so abstract, and everyone experiences it differently. Some people are easily entertained by simple things, while others are more difficult to amuse. These differences make interacting with others enjoyable.  As I've said, humans like to laugh and make others laugh. No matter how you interpret the abstract nature of laughter, you have to admit it's kind of funny.

Someone once told me that laughter is the key to comfort, and I believe it's one of the most important aspects of any relationship. It brings people together.  About two years ago, in the middle of fall, I was crying because my dog had passed away. My ex - boyfriend tried everything to comfort me, but nothing worked. Sharing @ORGANIZATION1 (laughter) is one of the greatest joys in my life. I can't imagine life without it. During a particular @DATE1, my cousin @CAPS1 and I were together. I've always believed that "laughter is the best medicine". I can laugh all day, finding almost everything in the world funny. Laughter is crucial to me; without it, life would be dull. Sometimes, genuine and heartfelt laughter is wonderful, but other times, laughter can be cruel and mean. I prefer to steer clear of the latter and focus on the good kind. When my friends are laughing and smiling, I'm eager to know what's so funny so I can join in. Birthdays are always fun, and laughter usually accompanies that fun. I remember my twelfth birthday. I decided to have a party at my house. I wanted it to be truly special, so I invited my closest friends and my cousins. Family always adds a special touch to everything. My cousin and I are very close. She was born nine months after me, so we're the same age for a short while. We always have a great time, acting crazy and laughing non - stop. For the party, my mom made rainbow sherbert punch, which was delicious. Everyone had a blast, and when the party was over, my cousins stayed until the next day, so we kept the fun going. I was in the kitchen getting more punch when my cousin came in and wanted some too. I poured us both a glass. My cousin said, "This is so good!" I replied, "I know. That's why I had my mom make it. Do you wanna hear a joke?" She said, "Sure." I told her, "Once there was a kid named butt itches. He was really sick and one day died. His mom cried to the doctor, 'Oh, my poor butt itches!' And, do you wanna know what the doctor said?" She asked, "What?" I said, "Itch it!" She had just taken a drink of punch when I told the joke. She spit the punch out while laughing, and it got all over me. Usually, when someone spits or spills something on you, you'd get mad. But I started laughing hysterically, and so did she. She said, "Oh my gosh! That's so gross." We couldn't stop laughing. The joke wasn't that funny; it was the punch all over me and the kitchen. We laughed for at least fifteen minutes before we realized our moms were standing in the kitchen, just staring at us, wondering what on earth had happened. Laughter made that birthday extra special, and I'll never forget it.

I've often heard that laughter is the best medicine, but there are times when it can be a double - edged sword. In my first - hand experience, laughter has both broken my heart and motivated me to transform myself. In the first grade, all first - graders seemed to have an urge to bring others down to build themselves up. I was a first - grader whose weight had become a concern, and my doctors advised me to look into a weight - loss program. This news was already crushing my self - esteem, and my classmates' laughter only made it worse. I remember a particularly bad day on the bus. I was almost home when four girls I thought were my friends started laughing. I joined in, thinking it was just some innocent giggling. Then one of them blurted out, "You look like a beached whale!" The whole bus heard and burst into laughter. That day, the street where the bus dropped me off seemed gloomier than ever. I decided I'd never set foot on the bus again. However, this painful encounter gave me the motivation to lose weight and regain confidence. Over the years, I've lost 60 pounds, become a varsity cheerleader, and am proud of who I am. But sometimes, I catch myself making jokes at others' expense. Just the other day at the mall, my best friend pointed out an overweight girl and started giggling. My initial reaction was to laugh, but I immediately felt the same pain I'd felt on the bus. I stopped, realizing the harm my laughter could cause. Laughter is a powerful thing, and while it can bring joy, we must be careful not to use it to hurt others. I hope my story can open people's eyes to the harmful effects of unkind laughter.

Laughter is an integral part of my life, and I firmly believe it's essential for a good and healthy relationship. It has a remarkable ability to lift my spirits when I'm feeling down, benefiting my body, mind, and soul. My mother and I share a wonderful relationship filled with laughter. We laugh at the silliest things. She can make me laugh at the most ridiculous moments, and she's the only one who can make me spit my drink all over the dashboard with a simple silly face. I also had an interesting conversation with a good friend about the way people laugh. We noticed that people usually laugh in vowel sounds like a, e, and o, and we decided to try laughing in the vowels i and u. It was a fun and unique experience, even though no one really noticed our odd laughter. There was also an occasion when my mom and I were at my aunt's house. We decided to try a facial cleansing mask we saw on TV. The mask was made of whisked egg whites and toilet paper. We dipped the toilet paper in the egg whites and plastered it on our faces. We had to wait at least fifteen minutes for it to dry. When we saw the final results, we looked like a bunch of crazy ladies, and it was incredibly hard not to laugh. I had to leave the room for fifteen minutes so my face could dry. When I came back, I found my mother and aunt in the bathroom drying each other's faces with a hair dryer. I couldn't hold it in any longer and started crying with laughter. My mask cracked, and all my hard work was wasted. That day was one of the funniest of my life, and we laughed so hard that our abdomens hurt. I love to laugh, and I have different forms of laughter. When I laugh really hard, I sometimes forget to breathe. Laughter has made a huge difference in my life, and I don't know what I'd do without it.

Laughter is my key to getting through tough days. It gives me hope and brightens my mood, whether I'm going to work, school, or any other activity. She inspires me to aim higher in life. When we're together, one look at each other can set us off into fits of laughter. Sometimes we laugh hysterically over nothing, but that's what it's like when you're with your best friend. Laughter is important in all my relationships. It shows me a person's sense of humor and their ability to be fun and not a stuck - up perfectionist. My friend and I often talk about boys and boy problems, which makes me laugh and giggle. In our fifth - period forestry and fire class, we're like caged monkeys. We have sudden bursts of energy, tickle each other, and laugh loudly.
