We make fun of my sister who was supposed to be a boy, my brother as the only boy among five kids, and my sister for being the shortest. Laughter makes me feel alive. It motivates me for the day and helps me communicate with others. I'm grateful for the ability to laugh because without it, I'd have a hard time making friends.

The beautiful flames in the night air danced peacefully. The faint glow of the blaze was our only light. As I carried sixty pounds of wood from one side of the house to the other, I felt like someone was watching me. When I finally reached the trailer, my best friend's mom, [Mom's Name], said she didn't think we'd need that much wood. I thought it was going to be a long weekend. After two hours of packing clothes, food, water, sleeping bags, pillows, and tents, we headed to [Campsite Name]. The two - hour drive felt like just twenty minutes. [Person 1], [Person 2], [Person 3], [Mom's Name], and I were a rowdy group in the car. We yelled, fought, and punched each other for fun. Once we arrived, we jumped out of the car like angry bees. After unpacking, I raced [Person 2] to the campsite. The first few days were spent in the hundred - degree heat, swimming, and flirting with girls around the camp. We slept as little as possible to enjoy our friendship. On the second day, we went mountain biking. After hours on the bikes, we noticed the sun was setting. We saw the most amazing view with bursts of orange and red, the colors bouncing from cloud to cloud. After the long bike ride, we went for a swim. While swimming, I felt something touch my foot. When I looked down, it was just a root system of a fallen tree, which looked so fake that it sparked a conversation about [Subject] for the next day. The sparks were dancing as if they were in some kind of celestial dance. The only light was the glow of the fire. [Person 3] was playing a beautiful melody on his guitar. As I was enjoying the beauty of nature, I felt someone watching me. I nudged [Person 3], and when we turned around, there was a spinning green light about twenty feet in the air. I said the word everyone was afraid of, [Subject]. I stood up slowly, and the light started spinning faster. I grabbed the machete next to me and approached the light. As I got closer, I could see small figures in the shadows. Then, there was an eruption of children's laughter, and a little boy ran out, laughing uncontrollably. After returning to my seat by the campfire, I thought about life. What if [Subject] were real and watching us? But I laughed it off and continued my week - long vacation.

What causes laughter? Laughter serves as an excellent stress - reliever. Globally, there are various types of laughs. Some individuals have high - pitched laughs, while others possess deep and low ones. There are also those who snort or make animal - like noises when they laugh. For me, different emotions trigger different laughs. When I'm upset, I have a distinct laugh. I often laugh when upset to improve my mood and have a better day. During a basketball game, I had a terrible night. Fouls were constantly called on me. Usually, in such situations, I get extremely angry, lose my composure, and end up on the bench, which I detest. This time, after being threatened with ejection in the previous game for the same foul, when another foul was called on me, I decided to smile and laugh it off. I told myself to shake it off. My coach was pleased with my change in attitude and advised me to play defense with my feet, ignore the bad call, and keep my head. When angry, one's demonstrative looks can have negative consequences, but smiling and laughing elicit different reactions. I'm not alone on my basketball team in this regard; many of us laugh off bad calls. I'm also a cheerleader. As a cheerleader, one should always appear happy. I play a basketball game every night before cheering. I need to stay calm during the game to be in a good mood for cheering. Laughing helps me stay composed and relaxed while playing. My coach emphasizes the importance of positive attitudes. She tells us at practice that smiling and laughing at mistakes lead to better outcomes than having a bad attitude. I took her advice to heart. Since then, I've tried to maintain a positive attitude by smiling and laughing when things go wrong. Laughter has far - reaching benefits. I believe it helps express our mood and is beneficial for the body. It can significantly improve one's mood when feeling down. I strive to be in a good mood always as I dislike being in a bad mood. Laughter makes me feel better. I think laughter is a great bodily function as it enhances my mood and those around me. It's a magical feeling that warms the heart. Everyone should laugh at least once a day to make their day better.

They say laughter is the "best medicine," but I don't agree. However, my nephew might have a different view. For two weeks, he pretended to be "sick" every school day. I'd tell his grandma, "He just doesn't like school." But his attitude towards school changed completely. We let him think it would be another dull school day, but it was a party day for the class. Every two weeks, if the students work hard, they get a party, and they'd been working hard this time. That morning, my nephew was being stubborn, resisting everything we tried to do. When we walked through the narrow classroom door, he did something unexpected for a five - year - old. He stood still and silent like a marble statue. The room was perfectly decorated! There were streamers, balloons, food, party hats, and bags. It was the first party of the year, and they'd really gone all out. The smell of the food made my stomach growl. There were all kinds of desserts like cakes, cookies, and pies, cooked just thirty feet away. As soon as you walked in, your mouth would fill with saliva. The children were as active as ninjas. One moment they were in front of you, and the next, they'd disappeared. It took me at least an hour to find my nephew in that small room. Eventually, I realized it was easier to sit and wait for him to find me. As I sat on the cold, hard, and uncomfortable floor, he suddenly appeared in front of me. He had an ear - to - ear grin that scared me because he only had such a big grin when he had a plan. And he did have a plan. In seconds, my face was wet. He'd been hiding a squirt gun behind his back and had planned his escape route. With the chairs and short tables in the way, it was difficult for me to catch up in the room. But once we got into the hallway, I could run easily. When I caught him, his grin disappeared, but we both kept laughing. Now, my nephew loves school. It's almost the end of his first year, and they still have great parties. Thanks to us, there are no more squirt - gun attacks. I think if we'd waited longer, it would've been harder to make him like school. He's a smart, athletic, and good - natured child. He'll do well in school, and with his strength, I feel sorry for any child who picks a fight with him.

I know you often hear the same things, and I also know many people don't answer the prompt properly. I'm sorry because I couldn't answer it either. I can't remember the last time I had a really good laugh in the past couple of years, so I'll tell you why laughter is special to me instead. What makes laughter special? For me, it's beneficial in numerous ways. I'll discuss how it's good for my health, how everyone's laughs are unique and can make us laugh at them, and why it's so special to me. After I laugh, I always feel a strange sensation in my head. I think it's because endorphins are being produced in my brain. If I laugh too hard, my stomach hurts because laughing burns calories and works my abs. I also believe it benefits all three aspects of the health triangle. Socially, I laugh with others. Emotionally, it makes me happy. Physically, working out with a friend is always fun. I think everyone's laugh is unique. Sometimes, it's amusing to hear people chuckle, snort, or sound like a mouse. Our laughs are part of what makes us who we are. Laughter is special to me because of the people who make me laugh. My friends are like family I've chosen. My family makes me laugh and happy every day. It's special because these people are special to me. Laughing with my father is different from laughing with my mother, and laughing with my friends is different from laughing with my significant other. Laughter is central to my life and is very special. It's not like chewing gum; it's a whole different experience. There's nothing more enjoyable than a girls' night filled with laughter or a romantic night of dancing. Laughter is essential for life. So, laugh, laugh, laugh.

Laughter has been a consistent and powerful force in my relationships. I believe it helps in getting to know new people and deepening bonds with those we care about. In my opinion, laughter can bring people closer and turn a bad situation around. When I was fifteen and a sophomore at [Organization1] school, it was my first year there. I'd attended many schools, like [Location1], [Caps1] wood, etc., and I was struggling to connect socially with my peers. My daily routine was boring: wake up, get ready, go to school, come home (maybe do homework), and go to bed. It was a cycle I seemed trapped in. Trying to be cool and fit in didn't work well. I realized that pretending to be someone you're not only gets you so far. What people, especially kids, like is when you're genuine. I learned this later; I didn't initially realize it was what people valued most. I decided I didn't like acting like someone else because I thought I was cool deep down. So, I started being myself. As it turned out, I was indeed cool, and girls found me attractive and funny. My ability to make people laugh or smile, aside from my looks, helped me make many friends I didn't have at the start. It even helped me win the heart of [Location2], the most beautiful girl I'd ever seen. She had a figure like a Coca - Cola bottle, caramel skin, and a face like a goddess. Like any beautiful girl, she had many admirers. But my greatest asset, laughter, came to my rescue. Although our relationship didn't last as long as I'd hoped, the time we spent together, the things we did, and the experiences we shared were priceless. It was all because I could make her laugh. I believe that without laughter, the world wouldn't be what it is today. There's still crime and horror, but imagine how much worse it would be without laughter. Joy, the core of laughter, allows us to forgive and overlook. Without laughter, it would be difficult to face the future.

Laughter can be the best part of life. It typically expresses happiness and joy. Laughter seems contagious; a single laugh accompanied by a smile can greatly improve someone's day. The great thing about laughter is that it's easy to come by as there are many things in the world that can make us laugh. I find myself laughing most when I'm with people I enjoy being around. Some think love, joy, or self - contentment is the key to happiness. I believe the key is surrounding yourself with loved ones because everything seems better when they're around. They're like sunshine, making everything brighter. My favorite memory full of laughter happened on a warm [Date1] day at my friend's house just outside the city. It was around [Num1] in the [Time1]. The air was warm but not overly hot; it was the perfect afternoon. My friends and I were having a great time: playing football, building a fire, and just being happy. We had everything needed for an amazing night. The most vivid moment was when we were playing catch. I threw a long pass to my friend, and as he ran to catch it, he ran straight into a fence. He got up laughing, and the laughter spread. That set the tone for the rest of the night. The rest of the [Time1] felt like it was out of a movie. Everything went smoothly, and we all felt great. It was the epitome of happiness. Laughter filled the air, and we all had big smiles on our faces. It was definitely my best memory of laughter.

Laughter is the essence of life. Without it, my life would lack meaning, and without that sense of happiness or compassion, life wouldn't be worth living. My sister is the sole person I trust with my secrets. She's the one who can make me happy when I'm feeling down. My sister and I share laughter over our own jokes. She's my other half, and we share everything. She makes me laugh and is always there when I need her, and I'll always be there for her. Laughter is an important part of life. My sister and I often laugh and play. One day, after getting off the school bus, all I could do was cry. As I waited for my sister's bus, the tears streamed down my face. When the bus appeared, so did a sense of joy. It wasn't the bus that brought me joy; it was my sister. Right away, she could sense my pain and noticed my tears. I could see the love and care on her face. She asked me what was wrong, and I could hear the worry in her voice. My tears stopped, and I began to pour out everything without hesitation. I told her what had happened without a pause. After that, she said something I'll never forget: "No matter what happens, I'll always love you." Then we laughed. It was the sweetest laugh, filling the air. I've learned to laugh at what others say about me because it's not true. Laughter truly enriches my life.

The night was dark and cloudy, casting a gloomy aura over my surroundings. Shadows danced across the street under the lamp - light of passing cars and pedestrians. My day had been a disaster, and it seemed that fate was against me. Everything that could go wrong did. And I feared the rest of the night would only deteriorate. Earlier that day, I'd upset my girlfriend with an ill - advised statement. As soon as I sat on my bed, she called. Our exchange of words left our relationship in shambles. The conversation ended in anger and a phone disconnection. Once I lay back in bed and my anger subsided, guilt overwhelmed me. I'd said unnecessary and horrible things. As I lay there, my heart felt like it was being squeezed by an invisible force, making it hard to breathe, and soon tears welled up in my eyes. The guilt and agony invaded my soul like a burglar in a dark house, stealing my peace. My day ended in tears and pain. But then my phone rang again. I quickly wiped my tears and checked the caller ID. It was my best friend. I answered, not knowing what he wanted. He asked if I wanted to hang out and grab a bite. His words lifted my spirits a little. When he pulled into my driveway, I was waiting. I got into the passenger seat, and he immediately knew something was wrong. He asked me if something had happened, and I simply said, "My girlfriend." He knew it wasn't the time to talk, so we drove to a nearby restaurant and found seats. We both ordered coffee. I started vigorously ripping open sugar packets and dumping them into my coffee, while he did it more gently. Then he cautiously asked if I wanted to talk. I looked up from the mess around my coffee cup and slowly nodded. I spilled out all the events of my day, swearing and using profanity. My best friend just listened until my voice softened and my fists unclenched. We sat in silence for a while. Then he changed the subject. He asked about my mother, and another stream of curses came out. After a short silence, he asked if I felt better now that I'd gotten it all out. I was a bit puzzled but thought about it and replied yes. We enjoyed our dinner, paid, and left. My mood had improved, though I was still a bit upset. We drove to the river and got out of the car. We stood by the bank, looking at the water. He asked if I wanted to hear a joke, and after a pause, I said yes. The joke he told was so funny that I laughed uncontrollably. His timing was perfect, and it made my mood soar. I've always turned to my friends when I'm down, and they've always been there. That day was a disaster, but the night turned out much better than I'd hoped. Laughter is truly a powerful force in my life.

Having friends who make you feel comfortable being yourself is perhaps the best quality in a friendship. Everyone has flaws, but a true friend can look past them and see the good in you. A friend can tell a joke and make you laugh until you cry. When someone thinks their life can't get any worse, a good laugh can turn things around. Laughter is the most precious gift. Just seeing the smile on someone's face tells you that you've made them happy. I've had many moments in my life when I've laughed so hard that I've cried. There's no better feeling than knowing you have people who can cheer you up with something ridiculous. I laugh a lot during the day. When I don't, people get worried, thinking something's wrong with me. That's how important laughter is in my life; it's like a second language. There was one particular night when my friends stayed over. We were just being boys, doing crazy things like eating hot sauce by the spoonful, watching comedy shows, and eating until we were sick. It was an unforgettable time, and we laughed non - stop. While watching the comedy shows, we couldn't breathe from laughing so hard. The comedian was like a master of words; his jokes were so well - crafted. I laughed and cried over and over again for about ten minutes straight. Making these memories with my friends is something I'll never forget. I'm truly grateful for the love and support I get from my friends and family. All my experiences, good or bad, teach me valuable lessons that will help me make the right decisions in the future. The laughs I share with others tell me they've had a good time, and it makes my day great too. Being myself around them is wonderful because I know they've accepted me. Everyone laughs at some point in their lives, even if they deny it. I'm honored to have such amazing people in my life who fill it with laughter. Life should be lived to the fullest, and laughter is a big part of that.

It's always difficult to know what to do when a friend or family member comes to you in a sad or angry state. Most of the time, you're at a loss. I've learned that making someone laugh with a simple joke can often make them feel better. One sunny afternoon, I was at home when I got a call from my friend PERSON1. When I answered, all I could hear was loud crying. I repeatedly asked her what was wrong, but she wouldn't say a word. I was getting really worried and asked her to calm down and take deep breaths. A couple of minutes later, she started explaining. She said she was irresponsible and hadn't paid attention to what was going on around her. I asked her why she was saying that about herself because I knew she was a responsible person. Finally, she screamed that while she was home watching the CAPS1 basketball team play, her dog CAPS2 got run over and died. I thought it was a bit ridiculous that she was crying so much over her dog, but I didn't want to be rude. I was confused about what to say, mainly because I was afraid of hurting her feelings. Finally, I told her not to worry and that my friend had some dogs for sale. I also said that if it would make her feel better, I'd buy her a new puppy. After that, there was an awkward silence. I was so nervous, thinking she was mad. Suddenly, she started laughing really loudly and couldn't talk. I was so relieved that I'd made her laugh instead of making her more upset. She laughed hysterically for a while. Then she stopped and started talking to me again. She thanked me for making her laugh and turning the situation around instead of saying depressing things. I was happy I'd made her feel better. I told her that anytime she needed to laugh, she could call me. I'd be happy to bring a smile to her face anywhere, anytime. She laughed with me and thanked me again. From that day on, I've always liked making people laugh because I know it makes them feel better, and I also love it when others make me laugh. It's a truly wonderful feeling.

Laughter is a crucial element in life. Without it, there would be no happiness or joy in the world. Friends are a great source of laughter; they're the people with whom you can be yourself. Some people use laughter to relieve pain. For example, my dad often laughs when he gets hurt. My dad was in the navy a few years ago. During training, he got hit in the stomach. It wasn't serious, but it did hurt, so he sat down and started laughing. I think this trait is hereditary because I sometimes do the same. I learned about the healing power of laughter not too long ago. It was last DATE3, early DATE5, and CAPS5 of DATE5 was approaching. She said we had to hurry because the next showing was in twenty minutes. I woke CAPS12 up, and we left. The movie was good. Afterward, CAPS12 went home, and the house was quiet. On DATE2, a day usually for relaxing, I was on my computer, my dad was playing video games, and my mom was in the kitchen making dinner. My dad went to help her, but she almost fell with some pans in her hands. My dad suggested she take a nap. Later that evening, my dad found my mother passed away in her sleep. I felt like my heart had exploded. A few days passed, and I found comfort in texting CAPS12. She mentioned how torn my dad was about my mom. Even though she was hurting, she and her friend tried to make everyone laugh because they knew laughter could ease the pain. That's why laughter is an important part of our lives. Someone once said, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." To me, this means that since everyone laughs, it is the quickest and easiest way to connect with others. I hold this belief because there was a time when my older brother and I didn't get along well. We rarely spent time together, and when we did, we either fought or ignored each other. Since he is five years older, it wasn't a major issue. However, as I grew older, we started seeing each other more often. One day, we decided to sit down and talk. We weren't sure what to say, so we sat in silence for the first ten minutes on the back porch in the middle of the @TIME1. For my family and friends, laughter is one of the most important elements of a relationship. With laughter comes happiness, and with happiness comes love. Love is the most crucial component of life. So, I firmly believe that "Laughter is the shortest distance between all people.

My journey with laughter began when I first met my boyfriend. Before that, I was constantly depressed, and my friends were fed up with my state. But when my friends introduced us, I fell in love for the first time. I was finally happy, no longer alone in a corner crying. It had been almost a year since I last smiled, and that happened the day I met him. My friends knew then that I'd found someone who would love and care for me as I am. As our relationship developed, laughter became a regular part of it. I was always laughing when I was with him, instead of being upset. It took the efforts of our friends to get us to hang out more. After that, we got to know each other better than when we first met. It wasn't until our freshman year that we started dating. Then, I found out that someone else thought I was dating him. I didn't believe it until that guy came up and started yelling at me. He said it was over, but I told him we'd never been dating in the first place. My friends saw me in tears and tried to find me someone new. By the time they did, I was with another guy, and I'm extremely happy with him. He's always there for me, no matter what. He's the best thing that's ever happened to me. When I'm upset or mad, he makes me laugh and says, "Don't worry, everything will be okay. Just believe in me." Laughter has been a part of our relationship for almost a year. We don't plan to change that unless one of us messes up again. We've made so many mistakes, but I don't know what I'd do if laughter left our relationship. It's an integral part of my life and our relationship. I hope it never changes because it's tied to him. He's the only one who can make me laugh when I'm crying, not even my friends or family could do that. Now that laughter is almost always present, I can't wait for sorrow to fade away. My relationship with him is so strong, and I'm not my bubbly self when he's not around. Some of my friends say I'm losing my bubbly self and shouldn't let it go. They also told my dad that I don't hang out with them much, and the reason is that they can be bossy and try to control me. They don't understand that this relationship won't work if they keep interfering. My relationship with laughter is between my boyfriend and me, and nothing, not even our parents, can change that. I just wish our relationship could have a happy ending without any outside interference. I hope nothing will tear us apart, and if it does, I don't know what the future holds.

I once heard a man say, "Laughing is the key to happiness, and if you do not laugh, you aren't healthy." Why do people love to laugh? Well, laughing creates wonderful memories, banishes sadness, gives you energy, and can even provide a good abdominal workout depending on how hard and long you laugh. There's nothing quite like a really funny movie that makes you laugh so hard that you cry, your jaw aches, and your stomach is sore the next day. Many of my favorite movies are comedies. I'm sure that laughing or making others laugh could give you an edge in getting a job. Suppose you're going for an interview for a job that involves daily interaction with people. You're not going to go in there dull and monotone. Instead, you'll make the interviewer laugh and act as if you've known them for ages. However, laughter can also be misused. It can be used in a hurtful way, like making fun of people. For example, calling kids in gym class names just because they can't throw a baseball as far as you. Laughter can either make people feel on top of the world or as bad as a basketball player missing the game - winning shot at the buzzer. We need to be cautious when using laughter, treating it like a loaded gun because using it wrongly can hurt someone. A few hours after my @CAPS4 passed away, my family and I started sharing good memories we'd had with her. I noticed tears streaming down my @CAPS5 @PERSON1's cheeks. Then, we began to talk about the times she'd get really mad and swear at my dad when he was a boy, and then get embarrassed for using the Lord's name in vain. Thinking about those moments, we started to laugh, not just a small giggle but full - blown, loud laughter. That laughter dispelled the sadness that had filled the room all night. I'll always remember how that laughter that night became such a powerful and emotional memory for me later in life.

Laughter is incredibly important in my life. Without it, my life wouldn't be as amazing as it is now. My friends, family, and boyfriend are the ones who bring so much laughter into my days. I have numerous stories where laughter played a part, but I'll tell you about how my boyfriend used laughter to help me forget about my stomach ache. It all took place on a @DATE1 @TIME1 as I was on my way home from my boyfriend's house. We were on the max, and my stomach started to hurt. I told my boyfriend, and he thought it was because I hadn't eaten. I was worried since it was going to be a long trip. On the way to my house, my boyfriend tried to distract me from my stomach pain. He asked me about my school day, and I said it was okay. As we talked, he suddenly took off his hat and said, "From flat to volume!" I burst out laughing. I laughed so hard that my stomach, which had ached from not eating, now ached from laughing. His hair was all messed up and looked so funny. I asked him why his hair was like that, and he said that when he was showering, he'd grabbed a shampoo bottle that promised to add volume, and he didn't expect his hair to get so voluminous. The whole way home, I couldn't stop laughing about his hair, and I completely forgot about my stomach ache. Even to this day, I still laugh when I think about how his hair looked that day. We have an inside joke now. Whenever I remember that day, I say "From flat to volume," and we both start laughing. I've realized that laughter is the best medicine for me when I have a stomach ache. Laughter will always be an inseparable part of my life, no matter what happens.

Have you ever pondered how you and your closest friends became friends? Perhaps not, or maybe you have but can't recall. Well, today I'm going to share the story of how my friend @PERSON3 and I became friends. I'll also tell you how we've remained friends for so long and all the little things that have kept our friendship strong. Initially, we weren't the kind of friends who were constantly laughing. Instead, one of us was a crier and the other a helper.  @PERSON3 and I first met in the eighth grade. I was called out of my first - period class and greeted by my math teacher, @PERSON1. @PERSON1 informed me that we had a new student who had moved here from @LOCATION1 and wasn't very happy about it. She asked if I'd mind showing the new student around the school with another classmate, @PERSON4. I agreed and entered the room where @PERSON3 was. The first thing I noticed about her were her tear - streaked eyes. Then I realized she was a very pretty girl who, as @PERSON1 had said, was unhappy. I'll admit I was a bit afraid to show her around since she clearly wasn't thrilled to be here.  Once we started, she calmed down significantly, but she wouldn't even crack a smile at our feeble attempts at joking. I decided to go all out. I walked in a funny way, talked in a comical voice, and even said random funny things during long pauses. Eventually, she smiled, and I kept going. By the end, I got her and @PERSON4 laughing so hard that we all nearly wet ourselves. This wasn't the last funny thing we did. You know those funny moments that you always remember when you see the person you shared them with? Well, @PERSON3 and I have many such moments. Many of them involve other people, which makes them even more fun.  For example, in our drawing and painting class, @PERSON3, @LOCATION2, @CAPS1, and I were in @PERSON2's office getting a picture to draw. I'd been hyper all day, and so had @CAPS3. I randomly looked around the room and saw a really cute poster I'd never noticed before. Without realizing it, I said aloud, "@CAPS2, that's really cute." @CAPS3 started laughing and held onto the desk to keep from falling. I was confused because I didn't realize I'd said it out loud, but I was also laughing because watching them laugh was so entertaining. They finally calmed down enough to tell me what I'd said, and I blushed but continued laughing.  Now, every time they see me and remember that moment, they burst out laughing and imitate what I said. I believe these big, funny memories have kept our friendship together. They help us recall the good times during tough moments and strengthen our bond within our group of friends.  The little things matter too. Every small, funny thing we do as friends is beneficial. If we only had big funny moments or boring ones, our friendship probably wouldn't last. Like when we accidentally burp or fart while walking, or when I laugh and hide my face with my hands and my arms jiggle, or when we say something weird or walk funny because we need to use the bathroom. It's not just being friends that keeps us close; it's how we are with each other. I feel like I become a better person when I'm with her, and I think I help her become a better version of herself too. The little things are just as funny as the big ones.  As I've said, laughter is a crucial part of our friendship. It started with tears and grew into laughter. Laughter brought us together in a strange way, and our friendship has remained strong. It's not because we have a lot in common (frankly, we don't), but because of the big, hilarious moments we've shared, both with each other and with others, and the little, everyday funny things we do. I truly believe that laughter is the best thing to keep any relationship healthy and happy.

I was told as a child that laughing makes you live longer, and I firmly believe that laughter is incredibly important in life and relationships. With my sister @LOCATION1, we laugh all day, every day, and that's why we have so much fun together. I laugh the most when I'm with my friends. You should be yourself, laugh at the things you find funny, even if others don't. Who cares what others think? Just be you.  I absolutely love it when babies laugh. To me, a baby's laugh means that the baby will grow up to be a happy person. In movies and TV shows, I sometimes find myself laughing. Laughter is a sound I adore, and it plays a huge role in my life. It's the only thing that can keep me going during tough times. Sometimes, it's even better than ice cream, and that's saying a lot. Similarly, when I got dumped, laughter made me feel as if nothing had happened. I truly believe that when people are going through a rough patch, laughter can make everything seem a little better.  Hearing that my brother was back in jail was like a brick hitting me in the head. He'd just been out of a four - month sentence three months ago

Laughter is something we all need. It serves as a reminder that there is hope for those with perseverance, those who strive to better themselves rather than others. It reminds us to live our dreams instead of merely dreaming of living. In my view, most importantly, it's a reminder that even when we make mistakes, there's still a chance for those with the courage to seize it.  On a certain date, my foster parents decided to go out for dinner. The children weren't invited. We could either stay home with the babysitter or go to a friend's house. No one wanted to stay home as there was nothing to do. One of my best friends, PERSON2, was a single child living with her grandmother. I made a quick call, and ten minutes later, I was waiting for her grandmother to pick me up. It was around five in the evening, and I had to be back by nine. I had four hours, and it was two weeks before an event. Neither of us knew what to do with so much free time. We only saw each other a few hours at school, so this was new to both of us. We were sophomores, and I had a crush on LOCATION1. This became a problem because PERSON1, her boyfriend, knew about it. He didn't have an issue with it initially, but he didn't like me spending so much time with her when he wasn't around. However, he trusted me to take care of her, so he didn't make a big deal.  We decided to set up the tree first. We both had shiny decorations, so the tree was full of tinsels, ornaments, pictures, and more. It took about twenty minutes to set everything up, not including unpacking the decorations. It looked amazing when we finished. I'd helped make nice - looking trees before, but this was the best. I was proud of our work. In my life, I didn't have much to appreciate, so this seemingly unimportant thing became really significant. We admired our work for a few minutes and then went to the den. PERSON2 got on the computer to talk to PERSON1, while I texted my girlfriend. I was preparing to break up with her.  I'd been with PERSON3 for most of my sophomore year and was starting to regret it. Our relationship began when one of my buddies, PERSON4, and hers ended. At first, I didn't want to be with her. I was trying to stop them from fighting. Now I understood why PERSON4 broke up with her. She was like a bad drug that made you high and then dropped you. She was extremely controlling. She wasn't right for me, and PERSON2 had convinced me it was time to end it. After the breakup, I felt both happy and depressed. I was happy to be free but sad because I felt alone. I wasn't good at getting close to people, so this was hard.  Seeing me so upset, PERSON2 knew I needed help. She did something subtle. She looked at me, got up from the computer, and gave me a long hug. At first, I thought it wasn't a good idea as her boyfriend was protective.  "Please just try to relax for a minute. You're making me nervous," she said in an authoritative tone. Maybe because I was in a bad mood, this seemed incredibly funny, and I started laughing hard.  "See. That wasn't so hard, was it?" As she pulled away, I kissed her forehead as a way of saying she was beautiful.  "Are you going to be okay?" she asked worriedly.  "Yes, I'll be fine. Thanks, PERSON2."  "Come on. You never showed me that guitar thing."  "What guitar thing?"  "You said you played guitar." Then I realized I might not find a friend like this again.  "Okay. Come on. I'll show you how to play, man.

Over the years, people have formed bonds that are strengthened by laughter, joy, and trust. These elements are all important and work together to build these connections. For people to enjoy each other's company, they must have fun, and fun often starts with laughter. Laughter originates in the brain, and when two people find the same thing funny, it brings them closer due to their shared interests.  As a child, I was always a happy and easy - going kid. My parents always told me, "People that are happy are the ones people want to be around." Being a seemingly happy person has helped me make friends, though I never fully understood what it truly meant as it could have multiple interpretations.  When I'm with my friends, we're always laughing or joking. We might laugh at ourselves, at a random person on the street, or even at nothing in particular. Sometimes, we start a funny argument. If someone says something stupid, we try to make them sound even more foolish. Most of the time, we don't get offended, but sometimes we take it too far. The shared laughter has kept us friends.  Stupidity and pain are two common reasons for our laughter. Stupidity could be someone saying something nonsensical or at the wrong time. I've never understood why we laugh at pain. Maybe it's because we're glad it's not us in pain, or we know the person will recover. When someone is badly hurt and others laugh, they may get angry, but they should realize that it's a natural reaction and that they also laugh at similar situations.  Laughter is crucial for building relationships. It reveals common interests and shows what people can tolerate in others. It's the main ingredient for bringing happiness into our lives. Without laughter and happiness, the world would be extremely dull.

Laughter is a mysterious phenomenon that occurs whenever it pleases and brings smiles to people's faces. My experience with laughter led to a crazy and messy situation.  Around two months ago, on a cold day, it was my birthday. I threw a small party at home. When everyone arrived, they had smirks on their faces. Then, my friend PERSON3 and my boyfriend PERSON1 walked into the kitchen with a large bucket of spaghetti and a big can of tomato sauce. I was shocked and couldn't understand why they had so much. My mother then said, "Load up the cars, and let's go!"  As we approached the place, I had a strange feeling. I noticed my sister - in - law holding a video camera and knew something big was about to happen. And it did. Spaghetti flew everywhere, getting in people's hair and on their faces. Clothes were stained. It was cold, wet, and rainy outside, and the fog made it hard to see who was throwing and being hit. By the end, I looked the worst, and my shoes were still stained.  When we got back home, we had to wash with the hose. I thought I'd get sick from the cold water. I could feel noodles and sauce on me as we all laughed at each other's messy appearance.  Eventually, we got hungry and decided on nachos. My mom put out a large amount of chips and cheese with jalapenos and olives. Things got even messier. My friend dropped nachos on the couch, and there was a food fight. Nacho cheese got stuck in my dog's fur and the girls' hair, and chip crumbs were everywhere. PERSON3 finally said, "No more nachos!"  Then it was cake time. Everyone sang the birthday song. My mother was crying in the background as she always does on birthdays, thinking her kids are getting closer to leaving home. Suddenly, frosting was on my face. I smeared it on PERSON1, and he put it back on me.  After that, we played video games. I got angry at someone in the game and threw the controller at the TV, breaking it. My mother wasn't happy. People started leaving, and I was left with a huge mess of chips, cheese, and cake to clean. It took over three hours, but it was all worth it because we had so much fun and laughter. Laughter is everywhere, and even though it can create chaos, it brings people together and makes life enjoyable.

Laughter has a dual nature in our lives. On one hand, it can be a great benefit, while on the other, some people think it can create distance in relationships.  I'm one of those people who can laugh at simple things that may not seem funny to others. I believe laughter is an important part of who we are. It shows others how we express ourselves and gives them an insight into our personality. Friends and family can understand what kind of person we are and how silly we can be. That's why I think it's great to just have fun and laugh.  In relationships, laughter is extremely important. It helps us get to know others and for them to know us. It reveals how a person reacts to different situations and whether they have a sense of humor. When people lack humor, they may not understand jokes. Laughter can tell us if someone is fun to be around. It also allows us to understand a person better in any relationship.  However, some people think laughter can distance two people. I don't agree with this view. There are people who laugh a lot and don't have any issues with others. In fact, they may attract more friends because they seem fun to be around. I laugh a lot, and it has only helped me make more connections.  In my opinion, laughter is a vital part of our identity, our way of thinking, and our interests. Sometimes, we may hold back from laughing because we're shy or don't know someone well. But we should laugh whenever we want. Laughter can make us the happiest and funniest people, and we can also use it to cheer up sad people. Overall, laughter is a powerful tool that enriches our relationships and our lives.

There are times when I get along well with others and times when I don't. There are also moments when I make others laugh so hard that they cry.  One time, my friends and I were walking to the store. I started pointing out random things. When I pointed out the @CAPS1 store, one of my friends laughed so hard that he peed his pants. We had to go back to his house so he could change. It took him between @NUM1 and @NUM2 minutes to get dressed. I asked what he was doing, and he said, "I'm taking a pee." That made me start laughing and rolling on the floor.  Then I realized why he had laughed so hard at me pointing out the @CAPS1 store. The last time we went inside, there was a man talking about his son's football team, which my friend and I were on. The man said the team was in the top ten, but we actually weren't. The man was worried about what the lady he was talking to would think of him. So he got up and said, "Thank you for letting me know that. I thought he was right for a second." He gave us a hug, and another man said, "What about me? How come I don't get a hug." That made me laugh even harder. Thankfully, I didn't have to go to the restroom at that moment.

@CAPS4 fills the surrounding air with happiness and joy. It evokes warm memories of close - loved ones and offers a glimmer of hope to those in need. It can come from a poor joke someone tells, a show, or the joy of a loved one's long - awaited return. A single shared laugh can initiate a friendship that may last a moment or a lifetime. In my case, @CAPS3 led to one of my closest friendships. In class, a student tried to be cool by climbing the flagpole to replace the @ORGANIZATION1 state flag with his homemade one (he got the idea from a show). Half - way up, he got scared and yelled for help. It took the faculty almost half an hour to get him down. That was the moment I made an amazing friend. Many friendships are formed in class or at work, but a great one often starts with a shared laugh. @CAPS3 is the name of @PERSON1, the son of @CAPS2 and @PERSON2. In @CAPS3's story, @PERSON2, @PERSON1's mother, said she was surprised when she had her only child, and people would be as surprised and laugh when they heard the news. Surprise can also make people laugh. I remember when my mother lost the house keys in the car. We searched everywhere but couldn't find them. After an hour, we called my dad to bring the spare key. As soon as he parked, my mother found the lost key in her pocket (a typical cartoon moment). We were shocked and then burst into laughter. Being surprised can bring a smile and a laugh. My sister and I often stare at each other blank - faced, trying not to laugh, but end up laughing non - stop for no reason. We can't even stare at each other for a minute without starting to laugh, and we often laugh for an hour straight. When we stop and realize we were laughing for no apparent reason, we start laughing all over again. @CAPS3 represents the deep connection between two people, where they can understand each other's thoughts. Laughter can come from holiday family gatherings, school friendships, childhood memories, and the realization of how silly our past fads were. It can also come from being surprised or knowing someone deeply.

Laughter is a daily part of my life. When I laugh, I experience a range of emotions, including happiness, sadness, and pain. I use laughter as an outlet for these emotions. Usually, laughing makes me feel happy, except when I'm crying due to being hurt. When I'm sad, I often laugh and smile to hide my pain. I don't want people to think I'm seeking attention by playing the "sad card." However, sometimes laughing when I'm sad actually makes the pain worse. But I rely on laughter to get through my day when I'm sad because having people constantly ask what's wrong would drive me crazy. When I'm angry, I can only laugh if a friend or family member tries to cheer me up or if I'm remembering fun times. Laughing when I'm angry brightens my day. I also laugh at hurtful comments to hide my feelings. When I'm happy, I just smile and laugh. A happy laugh can really brighten my life. My friends and I can sit around and laugh for hours without any particular reason. We're often silly together, and that makes me very happy. My nephew, family, and friends are some of the things in my life that make me laugh. Whenever I think of laughter, these things come to mind. I firmly believe that everyone needs some laughter in their life to be happy.

Laughter can be found anywhere. It might be in a cozy living room three doors down, at a local playground on the teeter - totter, or at an elegant restaurant in a corner table. For me, it was in an old fifth - grade classroom. I walked through the door with a purple backpack on my back and a lunch pail in my left hand. He seemed nice, like most teachers, but nothing extraordinary. The day dragged on. The students got sleepy, and the excitement faded. The day ended, leaving the eager kids disappointed. The next day, I reluctantly went back to the classroom. To my surprise, it was completely different. Every wall was filled with colorful posters. There was a popcorn machine in the back, overflowing with fresh popcorn. The smell filled the air as we entered. Mr. @CAPS3 sat at his desk as we took our seats. He welcomed us to the second day. Soon, I found that the rumors about him were true. He had a simple sense of humor that made everyone in the class giggle. His ideas and words related to us as fifth - graders. His subtle jokes entertained our young minds. He talked, acted, and joked like us. He even gave each of us a customized nickname. Laughter constantly filled the classroom. During class reading, weekly popcorn servers would distribute bags of popcorn to the kids. The class got excited for jeopardy games, quickly forming teams. His classroom became a place we never wanted to leave, with hour - long games and water - chugging contests. Despite all the fun, @PERSON1 taught us what it means to be a learner. He cared about our future and pushed us to strive in life. He taught us to write with passion and express our feelings on paper. He spent one - on - one time with struggling students, and their confidence grew. He could understand us and bring out our hidden confidence. We respected him and felt comfortable joking around with him in class, just as he did with us. @PERSON1 made us eager to learn. One day after school, as I was walking home, @PERSON1 stopped me at the door. "Hi, @PERSON2C!" I said excitedly. He chuckled and asked, "Did you have fun in class today?" "Yeah," I replied with a grin. "I'm glad," he said, then changed the subject. "I'm thinking of having a big dodge - ball tournament at recess tomorrow. Do you think it would be a good idea?" I was surprised that an adult was suggesting such a fun thing. "That would be so fun," I said. "Great," he said, "you're a really nice kid. It's a lot of fun having you in class." I was overjoyed. After our conversation, I continued home. Every student in the class wanted @PERSON1 to like them, as if he were the most popular kid at school. I was lucky to be liked by him, the man who changed my view of education and life. Sometimes, I think back to those carefree fifth - grade days and still laugh at the crazy things that happened in that small classroom. Laughter has left a deep mark on me and my classmates.

Laughing is essential in all my relationships. It lightens the mood and lifts my spirits on bad days. It's a great ice - breaker when meeting new people and helps me get closer to my existing friends. In my freshman year of high school, on the first day of school, I met a girl named @LOCATION1 in writing class. There was a boy named @CAPS1 sitting between us. @CAPS1 and I were talking about our schedules, and the conversation got a bit uncomfortable. I looked up and saw @LOCATION1, who seemed embarrassed for me and close to laughing. When @CAPS1 turned away, I mouthed "awkward" to her, and she started to laugh subtly. Little did I know that this first laugh would lead to a quick - blossoming friendship. After the first week of schedule changes, we found out we had all our classes together, except @CAPS3. We spent more time laughing in class than doing work, and I'm still not sure how we passed all our classes. Spending so much time together, we developed countless inside jokes. Just a word or a sight related to one of our jokes can make us laugh uncontrollably. Sometimes, we don't even need to say anything. A simple look at each other and we'll burst out laughing. Our friends often question our sanity when we laugh like this. They look at each other and then at us, trying to figure out why we're laughing or asking if we're okay. They don't understand our connection. People often mix up our names, even though we look nothing alike and our names don't rhyme or start with the same letter. But it's understandable because we're so similar in our interests and the way we think. @LOCATION1 makes me laugh every day, and she's one of my best friends. @CAPS4 is another friend who always makes me laugh. I'm always afraid of peeing my pants when I'm with her. She's not as close to me as @LOCATION1, but we've become better friends this year because we have many classes together. We do silly things together and laugh non - stop. For example, when our biotech teacher tells cheesy jokes, we laugh obnoxiously loud and exaggerate our "ha's." We also chew gum with our mouths open to make more noise. I often laugh so hard that I can't even chew. I know I'll have a great day if I'm with @CAPS4. Her laughter is so contagious that it comes from deep within, making it hard to breathe and bringing tears to my eyes. She's a really fun person to be around. Laughing is extremely important in my relationships. If my friends couldn't make me laugh, our friendships would be so dull. Without laughter, life would be no fun. Everyone needs laughter to be happy, especially in tough times. I'm grateful to have friends like @LOCATION1 and @CAPS4 who can make me laugh.

Laughter is like cooking; it brings people together, but just as the wrong food at the wrong time can cause discomfort (like beans), inappropriate laughter can have a similar effect. Laughter is a form of medicine and a universal language. You can communicate with a foreign friend through laughter even if you don't know their language. Laughter varies in loudness, pattern, softness, and attitude. We start laughing soon after birth and will likely laugh until the end of our lives. In life, it's important to laugh. It is forgiving and a sign of acceptance. During my freshman year, I arrived early at school to keep my friend company. Her mom dropped her off early due to transportation issues. We got into an argument, and I'm not sure how we got on the topic. My friend was criticizing me for something I did weeks ago. Our voices were getting louder. Although the argument didn't turn physical, our words were very hurtful. She was right, but her self - righteousness annoyed me. I thought that if she hadn't done what she did, I wouldn't have had any secrets to share. I knew I was also wrong, but I was focused on defending myself and not showing my vulnerability. "That only happened one time!" she declared as she tried to defend herself. "You didn't have to tell the whole world!" I retorted. "I didn't tell the world," I said. "I only told one person...who told one person, who told another person...and so on." She raised her eyebrow as if to say, "Really? You know what I'm talking about." The atmosphere in the room was tense, and our argument was going nowhere. We were both fed up with each other. She leaned back against the wall, trying to seem unconcerned, when her ankle slipped on the wet tile. She lost her balance and fell hard on the floor with a thud. Her pride was hurt, and all her coolness vanished. I tried to hide my satisfaction, but then I looked into her eyes and saw a sign of surrender. I tilted my head back, smiled at the ceiling, and let out a giggle. At first, I'm not sure what she thought, but slowly, she managed a chuckle. Our giggles turned into full - blown laughter, and we ended up lying on the floor. That cold, speckled tile became the place where we laughed away our anger. I apologized, and she accepted. Laughter made us forgive each other without many words. "That was funny," she said with a smile. The laughter we shared that morning carried through the day. As the saying goes, "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people." It didn't solve our problems, but it made us realize how silly our argument was. Her fall was the trigger, but it was our mutual decision to let go of bitterness and laugh that healed our relationship. Our laughter transcended our differences, and we were once again on the same wavelength, speaking the same "language" of understanding and friendship.

Laughter is one of the most wonderful feelings a person can experience. When in a negative emotional state such as sadness or anger, or during an argument, laughter has the power to transform these negative emotions into positive ones. Even if one tries to suppress this emotional shift, it is often difficult to do so.  In relationships, an abundance of laughter is crucial. Whether it is a soft chuckle or a boisterous outburst, laughter can completely change one's mood. Laughing with others is even more beneficial. Relationships filled with laughter are an important aspect of a person's well - being. Sharing laughter is an excellent way to initiate and maintain friendships. Without laughter, relationships are likely to end. It is nearly impossible to be good friends with someone without the ability to laugh together.  Laughter should be a regular part of relationships. Without it, there is a lack of connection, joy, and excitement. There is no common ground if two people cannot laugh together. People need relationships with humor as laughter can bond individuals of all ages.  For example, when I was a child, I would watch a video called "I Love to Laugh" countless times with my parents and siblings. Even now, when that video is mentioned, we fondly remember those days. The ability to laugh together has strengthened my family relationships.  Laughter is also contagious. It can ease a difficult situation and lift everyone's spirits. It is hard not to laugh when others are laughing. Everyone has their own unique way of laughing, and sometimes, a person's laughter can trigger laughter in a group. Making others laugh is a great feeling, and comedians build their careers on this very ability.  One of my favorite comedians is [PERSON1]. I appreciate his style and the way he constructs his jokes. He knows how to make people laugh. Every friendship should have someone who can boost the mood. However, the laughter should not come from mocking others but from the situation or circumstances the group faces.  The healing power of laughter is real. There have been studies on how laughter can heal the body, and laughter therapy is a legitimate treatment for troubled individuals. Norman [CAPS4]'s book, "Laughter is the best medicine," details the powers of laughter. [CAPS4] watched [The CAPS5 CAPS6] and laughed himself back to health, demonstrating the need for laughter in maintaining good health. If one's friendships lack humor, they should seek it out. Laughter is an essential feeling that one should surround themselves with throughout their life.

In this essay, I'll explain why laughter, conflict, and trust are vital in a relationship. I have an excellent relationship with my cousin, [CAPS1]. We've known each other for [NUM1] years. I love her more than anyone else in the world.  Laughter brings us closer. We laugh at each other's mistakes. When one of us makes an error, the other laughs and then tries to help solve the problem. We're always the first to know when something goes wrong, even if we don't like the person involved.  Conflict is also important in our relationship. We fight all the time, even over the smallest and silliest things. We protect each other from making life - altering mistakes and stop each other from doing really stupid things. We have a strange sense when the other is in danger or might be hurt.  Trust is the cornerstone of our relationship. We know everything about each other. If someone wants to know about me, they can ask her, and vice versa. I can tell her anything, and even if she might be mad at me for a while, I know she'll be there for me when I need her. We rarely judge each other for our actions.  My cousin is my best friend, like a sister, and more to me. We'll always laugh at each other's mistakes, have conflicts, but we'll always be there to support one another. These three elements - laughter, conflict, and trust - are what I believe are necessary for a good relationship, just like the one I have with my cousin [CAPS1]. I cherish this relationship and know she'll always be by my side.

The bell rang. There were sounds of shuffling, and then came [CAPS1]. A snap, a strange high - pitched sound, a crack, a slam, clicks, stomps, and more [CAPS1]. [PERSON1] and I looked at each other across the table and then burst into laughter. We laughed so hard that I cried. People around us laughed too, even though they didn't know what was so funny. It was an instant connection, like the one I had with my best friends back home. My chest swelled, my stomach ached, and my cheeks were sore. My heart felt whole. This was why I came on the exchange. Then the bell rang.

When I was nine years old, I didn't believe my grandfather when he told me that laughing could cure anything. Those days were dark and cold, and I felt like my life was a broken piece of a stained - glass window. My beloved pit bull, [PERSON2], had just died, and my little sister would tease me if I shed a tear.  I was sitting on the couch, staring at the crackling and popping fire when my grandfather sat beside me and told me a story. He said, "When I was young, I lost my best friend, [PERSON3]. We were eleven years old, and all we did was laugh. We thought we'd grow old together, be each other's best men, and cause trouble until the end. I loved him as much as you love [PERSON2]. I never thought anything would happen to him.  One day, [PERSON3] went fishing alone because I was at church and his dad had to work. It was a beautiful day to go down to the river, but he never came back." My grandfather sniffled and then asked me, "Do you want to know the cure for sadness?" I nodded, half - expecting a magical remedy. He said, "Laughter." I was shocked. He gently explained, "It's simple. Go through the stages of grieving, feel lost for a while, and then find your way back. Laughter is in your heart and always will be. Find joy and go with the flow. Love life because it can be short."  I nodded but didn't look at his serious face. He kissed the top of my head and looked into my eyes. I knew he saw the reflection of the fire in my watery green - blue eyes and could tell I was processing what he'd said. Then he left me to think.  I wondered how I could move on. Life wasn't that easy. To distract myself, I opened my notebook to do homework. That's when I found a small picture of me and [PERSON2]. We were in a mud pit; my blond hair was dirty from rolling in the mud, and [PERSON2] was rubbing his head on my shoulder, smearing more mud on me. I smiled, missing him more, but I also felt better.  After seeing the picture, I laughed to myself. I realized that maybe my grandfather was right. Laughter could be the cure for sadness.

On [DATE1], I turned [NUM1], and I was extremely excited. I asked my mom if I could have a party and a sleepover, and she agreed. That night, we planned the party and made invitations. He had gotten in through the window and jumped on the bookshelf, which wasn't sturdy enough and collapsed.

During a fourteen - hour flight, I was exhausted and barely knew the time. The bus I was on sped around sharp corners. Outside the windows, farmland, rocky bluffs, and peaceful rivers rushed by. Usually, making friends was easy for me, but this time was different. I had only a basic understanding of the language and culture of the people around me. The long flight was evident from the dark circles under my eyes and my greasy, knotted hair. My jet - lagged brain wondered how I would get along with these people. Would I fit in and adapt to @CAPS4 life smoothly?  We passed from the old - fashioned street to a dim, tunnel - like entrance. After a few turns, we entered an open courtyard. Several tables were covered with an array of food, and the smell of grilling bratwurst filled the air. "@CAPS18 you hungry? You should have something to eat. We have so much food here," @PERSON1 told me. I took a plate and put a roll, strawberries, and a sausage on it. I was too nervous to be truly hungry.  @PERSON1 guided me to a worn table with wooden benches where her friends were already having dinner and a few beers. She introduced me, and I sat stiffly on the edge of the seat. @CAPS14 talked excitedly, asking me about @CAPS15 life. As they relaxed, they started to joke, sometimes in @CAPS4 and sometimes in @CAPS5. Some of the @CAPS2 teased me about my accent. It wasn't mean - spirited; they just wanted to be light - hearted. So I laughed. At that moment, I felt more like a new friend and less of a foreigner. Relaxing, I allowed myself to laugh at my mistakes and really enjoy being in this new place.

My friend @PERSON1 and I have been friends since sixth grade. We've been through a lot together. Trust is of utmost significance in friendships. Friends concur on matters, express honest opinions, and safeguard the trust within a strong bond. My friends and I agreed to share everything and never lie, basing our friendship on trust. Once trust is broken, it's difficult to regain the same level. Communication may decrease, and one may be regarded as untrustworthy. For instance, a friend once hid the full truth from me. After I discovered it, my trust in her diminished, though we remain friends.  Trust is vital in friendships and all relationships. One day, when I was struggling to cope with significant changes in my life, I turned to a friend for help. Usually, on bad days, I keep to myself, but this time, I needed someone. I met my friend, and she did her best to cheer me up, but nothing worked. Then she asked, "Want to hear a story?" Eager to be distracted from my slump, I agreed, thinking it might help.  She began, "The other day, my family and I went grocery shopping. We were out for about four hours. When we got home, the parents started unpacking the groceries. Meanwhile, my sister and I were in the living room training our dog to sit, lay, shake, speak, and roll over. Every time the dog did a trick, we gave her half a dog treat. When the parents finished putting away the groceries, they came into the living room, and we showed them the dog's tricks. After that, my father said, 'Put the dog treats away so she doesn't get into them.' I simply replied, 'Okay.' Then the parents said they'd go get pizza as they didn't want to cook after shopping. While they were gone, my sister and I tidied up the living room and continued training the dog.  When the parents returned, we all sat down to watch TV and eat pizza. After a while, when everyone was done eating, my sister and I heard my dad in the kitchen complaining about not finding the cookies they'd bought. I said to my sister, 'Wouldn't it be funny if Dad thought the dog treats were cookies and ate one?' My sister giggled. Just then, my dad stomped into the living room, threw himself on the couch, and looked annoyed. We started laughing, and he scolded us. Then, out of nowhere, he said he'd found the 'cookies.' He reached for the dog treats on the coffee table. My sister and I were silent, watching him. He looked at the bag, took out a treat, looked at us, and then put the whole treat in his mouth. He started chewing, then slowed down, tilted his head like a dog, and choked. He coughed and spat dog treats all over my mom's head.  My sister and I laughed uncontrollably. My dad sat on the couch with a straight face, but then he started laughing too. We all laughed, and even my mom, who'd been sitting on the floor in shock, joined in.  After my friend told me this story and we both laughed until I cried, I realized that a little laughter can brighten one's day.

Have you ever felt the fear of falling off a cliff while in the mountains? I have had such an experience. Laughter brings enthusiasm and joy to any situation. Have you ever considered that laughter could be a key element in a relationship? Laughter makes you feel alive. It releases the pain in your life and gives you the feeling that everything is okay. As a typical teen girl, I blushed, quickly changed the topic, and tried not to make eye contact. But I couldn't help myself. The feeling of his eyes on my cheek overpowered my will not to look. I turned my head slowly, and sure enough, @CAPS5 was staring straight into my eyes. His eyes were wonderful, like sunflowers against a blue sky. For me, I laugh when I'm with the people I love. For some, it's watching TV shows they find amusing, or maybe their kids do something silly. The point is, laughter is everywhere. So, here's the goal: laughter is contagious. Try to spread a laugh. Do something that makes people remember it, and they'll start their own laughter. Let's embrace laughter!

Now, let's talk about friendships. People like friends who can make them laugh and have a good time. That's the kind of friends I have and cherish. Laughter is a vital element in a person's life, especially when one is in a joyful or happy state. In conclusion, laughter is an important part of life. It can bring people together, improve mood, and make life more enjoyable. Whether it's through jokes, pranks, or unexpected accidents, finding reasons to laugh can have a positive impact on our well - being.

Human beings are truly peculiar. There are billions of people in the world, including ourselves, and yet we often rely on others' approval to like ourselves. Even when others like us, we may still struggle to accept ourselves. What drives this behavior? We constantly use relationships to understand our identity, but it's a risky endeavor. We put so much on the line by depending on others; they have the power to either build us up or tear us down. As young people, one of our main goals is to find people who like us, and this need may persist throughout our lives. From my own experiences, I've learned that two crucial qualities in people who can build us up are trust and kindness. It's relatively easy to tell if someone with these traits can bring us joy. A kind person can make us happy just by being nice, but if we want to make a large number of friends quickly, kindness alone isn't the most effective approach. It's not that kindness is a bad way to make friends; it just takes time. To immediately recognize a friend, they should make us laugh. Laughter is essential for enjoying time with friends. In my view, it's a fundamental rule in the "book" of friendship. In @CAPS2 class, which was extremely stressful for me, laughter made the experience better. For example, during a class project, the instructions were given slowly, and I was on the verge of losing my temper. However, one day, the students seemed to understand the instructions right away and started working without asking for repeats. The assignment was for groups of three to four people to create a script using vocabulary from a booklet. It took a whole class period, and then we went home to do other work. My group was the first to perform. We selected volunteers and actors. Tiffany, @PERSON1, and I sat at the back of the classroom, not knowing what to expect from the actors. Our play was a huge success! By the end of the first sentence, everyone was giggling, and the laughter grew louder as the plays continued. More students volunteered to perform, and it became difficult to choose actors. Even I, who was usually aloof in the classroom, had a great time. The plays were fun and random, and some made everyone burst into laughter. I clearly remember one group making me laugh so hard that my sides ached, tears welled up in my eyes, and it was almost impossible to breathe. This project was the best I've ever participated in. Moments like these help build strong unity in the classroom. We learned to enjoy the company of our classmates and ourselves. I was so used to being annoyed with them that I was surprised by how much I enjoyed their plays. Now, I no longer see them as annoyances but as an entertaining group of students, like a family. It's amazing how something as simple as laughter can change our perception of others and ourselves.

Everyone has a unique way of laughing. Some laugh so hard that they cry, while others don't. However, the common denominator is laughter. Laughter serves multiple purposes, and it is a crucial element in relationships. The saying that "laughter is the shortest distance between two people" is indeed true. If you do, you'll realize that laughter truly has the power to bring people closer together.

Different people bring out different behaviors in us, but laughter is a universal element that can enhance any relationship.

Laughter is a natural reaction every human being has when they are either happy or have heard or seen something that is funny to them. It is healthy to be happy other than sad or mad. I firmly believe that laughter is of great significance. It's crucial to me because, for instance, if a student falls and you laugh at them just for the sake of it, it will surely hurt that student. In conclusion, showing respect through our actions and attitudes is the key to building a harmonious and caring environment among peers.

When extreme temperatures occur, the situation becomes extremely dangerous. In my experience, the extreme weather was a heatwave. I was eight years old and living in @LOCATION2, @LOCATION1. It happened in the middle of @DATE1, when an almost record - high temperature hit @LOCATION2. The temperature peaked at one hundred twenty - five degrees @CAPS4, and to make matters worse, the power in our entire neighborhood went out. Without air conditioning, many people got severely sick or injured. We lived in a gated community where everyone got along well. People in the neighborhood gathered, set up tents for shade, and provided cold water. When a situation like this occurs, there are important things to remember. You must have a good attitude because complaining won't help. You should also try not to focus on the heat and help those in need. I believe our community wouldn't have made it through if it weren't for everyone's positive attitude, spirit, and, of course, the laughter. Having a good attitude is crucial in such situations. What's the point of complaining and getting angry for no reason? I was told that it wouldn't last forever and to stay positive. I could tell that kids and adults who were complaining were having a much harder time coping. As an eight - year - old, it was difficult for me not to complain, but with the help of a lot of water, I managed. Keeping your spirits up and interacting with others makes the day pass faster. I remember when my whole family was under one of the tents, sitting around, telling funny stories and jokes. I'd rather have a day like that with my family than a normal, boring one. One of the most important things to do is to not think about the heat. If you don't dwell on it, you'll have a better time and won't complain. Keeping your mind off the topic helps you avoid stress. I saw many people who couldn't handle it. They only talked about how bad it was, and it was obvious they were stressed. If you try to make the situation positive and stop thinking about it, you'll get through it, no matter how bad it is. During this heatwave, many people needed help. The community was very helpful by setting up tents and providing water and snacks. However, the situation worsened as people suffered from heat exhaustion, and many had to be put on @CAPS5's. There were several ambulances to assist people and get them back to normal. Some people had to go to the hospital for further treatment. The community eventually got through the day with no serious injuries. The power came back on around six o'clock. Exhausted, people slowly walked or drove back to their houses. Our family walked home and immediately turned on the air conditioning. Everyone was relieved and happy to be out of that situation. Even at night, the temperature was still one hundred twelve degrees. We played games and told jokes the rest of the night and managed to get through it all. Our family stayed strong during the heatwave, while many others didn't. It truly shows that "Laughter is the shortest distance between two people.

When I was about ten years old, I was at the park with my grandma. I decided to put my head through the monkey bars. My grandma went to the bathroom, and I got stuck. I'll make sure we laugh as much as possible every day and never take our friendship for granted again.

When was the last time you lost yourself in a fit of laughter? Studies have shown that laughter releases endorphins, the body's feel - good chemicals. Laughter is an essential part of my life. Instead of writing about a single experience where laughter was key, I'll share a montage of true events that reveal who I am. I was a bit embarrassed when I got older and saw it on video, but now I can laugh at what was once embarrassing and move on.  Another time, we noticed that my initials spell a certain word. Whenever I swim with my brother and our friends, they sing the associated theme song, and I laugh. If I act like I don't care, they'll keep going, and they still haven't stopped. The teacher called my parents, who laughed and explained it was just a normal thing. Looking back, the teacher's expression was classic. I wasn't embarrassed; I just wanted to laugh. I've also found that I make jokes when I'm nervous during a speech. Once, in front of about 120 people, I made some not - very - good jokes, and I even hit my head on a dream catcher, but people laughed with me.  This organization has taught me that it's okay to cry at life's depressing moments, fear what scares you, love whomever you want, and live your life. Most importantly, it's okay to laugh at your mistakes. I'll remember this lesson and pass it on to my children one day. I learned this lesson while babysitting my sick cousins; it's a big responsibility. My brother helped me a lot. Thanks to the positive people around me, I've become a better person. I've learned to laugh when there's no way out, learn from and laugh at my mistakes, and understand that there's a deeper meaning to life. Remember, when life gives you lemons, make lemonade and have a good laugh with your friends.

My mom stayed with him, so my dad, sisters, and I had to take care of the house, which was a chore as I dislike housework. After about a week, they returned. My brother had a device on his leg to draw out fluids and giant screws in his leg attached to an external bar. He healed well and has a large scar. It was truly heart - warming to have the support of family and friends during this tough time, which is why laughter is so important in difficult situations.

In a romantic relationship, laughter is equally important. It builds character in the relationship and shows that you are content with your partner. It also paves the way for a good, strong, and healthy relationship, reducing the likelihood of divorce and conflicts. In conclusion, regardless of age, gender, or the type of relationship, laughter is of utmost importance. It helps in building a strong - willed person and adding character to oneself.
